content:
Posted: February 19, 2014
												READ THIS!To truly enjoy this game make sure to save often. Autosaves tend to screw you over IE they will autosave right as the door behind you gets locked and you cant double back for loot or something else. This is my main gripe with this game as I love exploring every edge of a game like this and sometimes the game literally blocks you from doing so when you've reached a certain point. Always make saves in case you need to backtrack so you don't have to restart from an earlier point.Also, make sure to check out the FOV bind with a quick google search, this will allow you to zoom out from Thornton(you) and allow better viewing specifically for widescreen users. This game is simply put; Awesome. It's like if Mass Effect went spy on budget. It's a really good game if you like RPG/TPS mechanics with (meaningful) leveling. If you play Recruit on Hard difficulty at first you will feel truly like a recruit and by the end you will feel like a freaking super spy of awesomeness. This game has an amazing element of evolving and also its dialogue tree which actually affects the outcome unlike other games of this genre (looking at you Mass Effect...) Allthough there are some INCREDIBLY annoying things about this game like how the AI will literally do a 180 once you shoot them and spot/simultaneously fire on you. Being a stealth character is more difficult then it should be as this game is mainly built around running and gunning but it's a fun challenge and by the end stealth+pistol became very OP and ultimately rewarding. If you enjoy Mass Effect type games and are willing to look past the occasional issues this game runs into(crappy autosaves, barely serviceable PC port, occasionally weak or unfair AI) it will result in a pretty fun experience that I'll be sure to replay once I unlock Veteran.

content:
Posted: August 21, 2016
Product received for free
												-First impressions, will have full review on the way.-Alpha Protocol is a third-person action RPG shooter with Stealth elements developed by Obsidian Entertainment, and published by Sega. Starting off this review, Alpha Protocol was a game i played when i was much younger, but i barely remember anything from it. So, my experience was bad, and i thought the game was bad, and it was a physical copy. It was around the time of release, so it had some issues, such as the issue i had myself, of completing a tutorial, but, it claiming that i haven't. Now for the review. Alpha Protocol contains an intresting narrative, and the game has a good tone, but just doesn't feel all so serious yet. The storytelling is also very good so far, and the game is reminding me of Mass Effect, the first game, which i thought was okay, but it did have really amazing storytelling, character development, and stuff. This game also has a dialogue system insanely similar to it, and it really, really feels just like that, although, the storyline isn't as good as Mass Effect. The characters are all very well written, and character development is also very good. For the gameplay, it does work well, and it makes me feel as if this is the Metal Gear Solid V: The Phantom Pain of 2010, or an early Metal Gear Solid V: The Phantom Pain. And talking about that, the gameplay has some unique stuff, but not much. It's the precision thing, and i like it. The gameplay isn't very tactical, but it is fun and induces you into creating strategies and stuff, using your mind, just like MGSV:TPP does, except, a lot of the gameplay depth and detail is removed here. Combat is also pretty damn good, although A.I is quite dumb at times. The graphics look top-notch, even at the time, but it doesn't stand out today, but it still looks good. At the moment, the game is very good, but we still didn't talk about the only problem i have with it, which is sadly slightly big. The game contains occasionally unresponsive controls. Anyway, i still think the game should get better, as the intensity of the storyline isn't quite gripping me yet, although it is intresting, it is really not bad, but so far, it feels as if it's gonna get much better. The gameplay, will too. The weapons? There aren't that many. I like the concept of Agent History at the start of the game, too, which you select actually before you get to play it. My experience so far with Alpha Protocol is good, and could nearly achieve a 9/10 with its gameplay, specially since the Stealth works very well.8.8/10 ~Only so far.This review will be updated constantly as i go through the game.

content:
Posted: November 8, 2014
												It’s third person shooter/RPG that is most similar to Deus Ex: Human Revolution and Mass Effect. The plot is very reminiscent of James Bond and other rouge spy movies.The story is actually pretty intriguing and decently written, involving different factions of spies, mercenaries, terrorists and secret police; taking you to places such as Moscow, Rome and Taipei.  Its interaction mechanics with NPCs during cut-scenes is the highlight of this game.  It allows you to chose different dialog choices that influences the story and character relationships. The cast of characters is colorful and they are all very interesting. Each NPC has a unique and different personality and a huge part/theme of the game is manipulating people to get what you want, that means acting aggressive, professional or suave depending on the person. Your relationships and interactions can also influence the way a mission plays out, whether or not you’ll receive back up, determining who are going to be fighting, and what items on the black market you can purchase. The game also emphasizes dossiers and gathering intel, which gives passive combat bonuses to specific factions and helps you learn about a character’s background so that you can learn how you’re supposed to talk to them if you want them to like you. Missions offer multiple paths, approaches and options. You can also bang MOST of the chicks in one play through, if you play your cards right (this is, hands down, the best part).Combat and controls can feel clunky, it seems like they wanted to make weapon specialization and stats like accuracy, stability and recoil matter in a third person shooter, so it forces you to ‘focus’ your cross hair on your target before you can shoot or else your shots will be all over the place.  This can make early game very annoying because your shots won’t focus fast enough, and any kind of long ranged combat becomes a pain.  The game forces boss fights, there is no stealth solution, you have to straight up fight them so it's highly reccomended that you pump up the stats in at least one weapon (fun fact pistol is over power). Regardless of the boss fights, playing stealth is generally over power, it rewards you with more stuff than a straight up commando/aggressive play, and it trivializes a lot of missions. There are 2 hacking mini-games, a word search and clicking tangled wires in a specific order. They get repetitive fast and are not really fun. The game can also be glitchy at times; there have been times when I’ve been spotted and never should have been (through a wall), times where I’ve gotten stuck in walls and had to die or reload my save, and the game had crashed on me 4 times throughout my play through.I’d recommend it if you like the talking parts of the Dues Ex and Mass Effect or just enjoy a good story driven game. You’d have to deal with the par combat, missions and maybe a rough early game.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 22, 2014
												Alpha Protocol is one big deception. The stealth action is lacking and the enemies sometimes act ridiculously. Because of this most of the missions are a drag. A shame since the created world lends itself perfectly for a spy game. The surprisingly fun conversation system, in which the choices have a real impact on the gameplay, is a spark in the dark mess called Alpha Protocol.Alpha Protocol is a strange game. No matter how good and deep is the RPG part, with a well told story, it's almost completely broke when it's time to shoot and sneak. The A.I. is so cheesy and random that completely make you forget your class and skills.Watch a Bourne movie instead.

content:
Posted: April 12
												So this game was much better than I expected.  I felt there were some areas they could have done better on though...The sniper rifle is not effected by mouse sensitivity. It was so aggrivating to move it just a hair and it would fly all over the place. Several games have this problem, I don't know why.The tranq bullets need work. I got a double head shot with a single tranq bullet Deadpool style. I'm no doctor, but I think the first guy probably isn't asleep...They said I killed marines in the embassy in Russia, I am almost entirely convinced I didn't. This may be a bug.There should have been a first person option. Some games have to be third person but many don't and I feel like this one didn't. Some tight spaces I couldn't see the enemy cause my character was blocking my view. I wish I shot more accurate. The chance to miss is fairly high, even with max rifleman.I personally didn't like hacking computer terminals. It was like a word search in middle school. I never liked word searches.------Random notes:Not a problem but I'd recommend you have one of your weapons the pistol. You really need tranq bullets to beat the game and the pistol has them.Also I'm sad I didn't kill all my enemies but that may be my own fault. I'm also curious about Sis and G22, sure I killed a lot of them but what ever happened to them?------Now, there were some amazing areas. Despite it's flaws, the combat system was a blast. I enjoyed the boss battles (even if they didn't make a lot of sense in an otherwise mostly realistic game)I enjoyed the four romance options, I especially enjoyed you can pursue all four. I disliked that they didn't really stick around. Maybe if you guys do a sequel you can pick up with the romance from the first game? Seems a waste to have the options but never do anything with them.The dialogue system was fun. -----I admit I haven't played many games like this, really only Mars War Logs and Of Orcs and Men but I would say this is the best of those three. I can't say how this compares to Mass Effect but I still recommend it.

												thinking of revisiting this game right now.i played more of it than just these 7 hours before i had this steam account.a good deal of it really.its basically an action/stealth RPG with choice and consequence and a coolnon linear espionage/ conspiracy story.id say the stealth and combat mechanics are very decent.i guess there are some flaws here and there but i cant think of anything right nowthat really took the fun out of it for me.the writing of the game is very good.. its obsidian after all..graphics are okay even though the game is fairly "old" now.honestly in my opinion at 15 bucks you can get a lot worse games and this game is actuallypretty damn good! i mean its not just okay and whatever but a game that you should at least try once.i have not expierenced any bugs or performance problems either.pros+ rpg elements, skills and stats and gear. (fairly decent selection in my opinion)+ interesting non linear story with nicely written dialogue, interesting characters and various settings from china to russia to the middle east etc+ good quality of animations, nice cutscenes, talented voice acting+ decent combat and stealth mechanics (nothing too special but nothing ♥♥♥♥♥♥ or boring either)+ choice and consequence+ aged but still decent enough graphicscons-loading screens during levels- while the AI is not "broken" it isnt the smartest either. sometimes you think wait? he didnt see me there?- like i already said there are loading screens some areas are bigger some are smaller.hardly a difficult sell. i dont understand the mixed reviews it recently got. its a  good game with high production value (at least for its time) done by obsidian who.. dare i say it? always delivers at least a somewhat interesting expierence. and they are charging less than most early access games on steam. (think about that!) and if you can get it on sale... well then its probably cheaper then a menu at mcdonalds.go ahead dont believe and try it.. it may be rough around the edges here and there... but its quite unique.

content:
Posted: August 21, 2016
Product received for free
												-First impressions, will have full review on the way.-Alpha Protocol is a third-person action RPG shooter with Stealth elements developed by Obsidian Entertainment, and published by Sega. Starting off this review, Alpha Protocol was a game i played when i was much younger, but i barely remember anything from it. So, my experience was bad, and i thought the game was bad, and it was a physical copy. It was around the time of release, so it had some issues, such as the issue i had myself, of completing a tutorial, but, it claiming that i haven't. Now for the review. Alpha Protocol contains an intresting narrative, and the game has a good tone, but just doesn't feel all so serious yet. The storytelling is also very good so far, and the game is reminding me of Mass Effect, the first game, which i thought was okay, but it did have really amazing storytelling, character development, and stuff. This game also has a dialogue system insanely similar to it, and it really, really feels just like that, although, the storyline isn't as good as Mass Effect. The characters are all very well written, and character development is also very good. For the gameplay, it does work well, and it makes me feel as if this is the Metal Gear Solid V: The Phantom Pain of 2010, or an early Metal Gear Solid V: The Phantom Pain. And talking about that, the gameplay has some unique stuff, but not much. It's the precision thing, and i like it. The gameplay isn't very tactical, but it is fun and induces you into creating strategies and stuff, using your mind, just like MGSV:TPP does, except, a lot of the gameplay depth and detail is removed here. Combat is also pretty damn good, although A.I is quite dumb at times. The graphics look top-notch, even at the time, but it doesn't stand out today, but it still looks good. At the moment, the game is very good, but we still didn't talk about the only problem i have with it, which is sadly slightly big. The game contains occasionally unresponsive controls. Anyway, i still think the game should get better, as the intensity of the storyline isn't quite gripping me yet, although it is intresting, it is really not bad, but so far, it feels as if it's gonna get much better. The gameplay, will too. The weapons? There aren't that many. I like the concept of Agent History at the start of the game, too, which you select actually before you get to play it. My experience so far with Alpha Protocol is good, and could nearly achieve a 9/10 with its gameplay, specially since the Stealth works very well.8.8/10 ~Only so far.This review will be updated constantly as i go through the game.

content:
Posted: November 8, 2014
												It’s third person shooter/RPG that is most similar to Deus Ex: Human Revolution and Mass Effect. The plot is very reminiscent of James Bond and other rouge spy movies.The story is actually pretty intriguing and decently written, involving different factions of spies, mercenaries, terrorists and secret police; taking you to places such as Moscow, Rome and Taipei.  Its interaction mechanics with NPCs during cut-scenes is the highlight of this game.  It allows you to chose different dialog choices that influences the story and character relationships. The cast of characters is colorful and they are all very interesting. Each NPC has a unique and different personality and a huge part/theme of the game is manipulating people to get what you want, that means acting aggressive, professional or suave depending on the person. Your relationships and interactions can also influence the way a mission plays out, whether or not you’ll receive back up, determining who are going to be fighting, and what items on the black market you can purchase. The game also emphasizes dossiers and gathering intel, which gives passive combat bonuses to specific factions and helps you learn about a character’s background so that you can learn how you’re supposed to talk to them if you want them to like you. Missions offer multiple paths, approaches and options. You can also bang MOST of the chicks in one play through, if you play your cards right (this is, hands down, the best part).Combat and controls can feel clunky, it seems like they wanted to make weapon specialization and stats like accuracy, stability and recoil matter in a third person shooter, so it forces you to ‘focus’ your cross hair on your target before you can shoot or else your shots will be all over the place.  This can make early game very annoying because your shots won’t focus fast enough, and any kind of long ranged combat becomes a pain.  The game forces boss fights, there is no stealth solution, you have to straight up fight them so it's highly reccomended that you pump up the stats in at least one weapon (fun fact pistol is over power). Regardless of the boss fights, playing stealth is generally over power, it rewards you with more stuff than a straight up commando/aggressive play, and it trivializes a lot of missions. There are 2 hacking mini-games, a word search and clicking tangled wires in a specific order. They get repetitive fast and are not really fun. The game can also be glitchy at times; there have been times when I’ve been spotted and never should have been (through a wall), times where I’ve gotten stuck in walls and had to die or reload my save, and the game had crashed on me 4 times throughout my play through.I’d recommend it if you like the talking parts of the Dues Ex and Mass Effect or just enjoy a good story driven game. You’d have to deal with the par combat, missions and maybe a rough early game.

												Alpha Protocol is one big deception. The stealth action is lacking and the enemies sometimes act ridiculously. Because of this most of the missions are a drag. A shame since the created world lends itself perfectly for a spy game. The surprisingly fun conversation system, in which the choices have a real impact on the gameplay, is a spark in the dark mess called Alpha Protocol.Alpha Protocol is a strange game. No matter how good and deep is the RPG part, with a well told story, it's almost completely broke when it's time to shoot and sneak. The A.I. is so cheesy and random that completely make you forget your class and skills.Watch a Bourne movie instead.

Posted: April 10, 2014
												I tried to like this game, I really did. After hearing absolutely damning reviews, I wonderd if this was going to be one of those 'Deadly Preminition' type games where the awsomeness and hilarity of the story makes up for it's abominable gameplay. Unfornately I was dissapointed.Enemies see you from 100 meters away in stealth. Even if you're behind something. Line of sight is completely broken.The guns feel like pea shooters and the combat system is flat out not there with basically one button to mash until you know the dude out. Movement is awkward and strange as the Protaganist seemingly proceeds to slide and float across the ground and the myriad  of glitches where I fell through the floor and got stuck.The story I never got to experience properly as I never got off the first level where I had to hack a door. The minigames are also mindbengingly annoying as it seems that it was designed for a controller. Dont bother with this. Unless you're getting this with the Humble Bundle, then I cant think of a reason for anybody to play this.

												So far, this game is very interestings combining an action/spy game with RPG elements. Now so far it is executed very well, stong graphics, great sound, fluid gameplay..AI is a little off at times and I can see this game becoming very difficult as you progress further. The small puzzles are great such as the Lockpicking, computer hacking and alarm disabling are nothing ground breaking but add to the the game. Being able to customize your player skills is fantastic and really shine as it hits right on the mark to add the rpg feel to the game. I would recommend this game for anyone who enjoys James Bond or Mission impossible style gameplay, with Martial arts, cover and many more features. This game seems to combine a little of everything which might be its downfall of trying to do to much but so far makes for a fantastic game! i would recommend while its on sale to pick it up!

content:
Posted: October 16, 2013
												I forgot I didn't have a recommendation for this game because I pirated it years ago.Anyway, the premise of the game is pretty awesome, and not really something done before, you're Micheal Thorton, a  bipolar and slightly psychopathic spy that gets betrayed by his own agenecy and has to go rogue to save the world. Well, more like save face for America, but close enough.   I'd go into praise about the gameplay here, but unfortunately Deus Ex: HR did almost everything this game did but better.  The stealth is wonky as ♥♥♥♥ (the developers probably realised this and literally made one of the skills make you go invisible the first time you are spotted) the combat trees are unbalanced, and worst of all there's level scaling, at the start of the game, people die when they are killed, and near the end russian gangsters are tanking headshots like they've been crocodil addicts their entire lives.I briefing mentioned the protagonist's mental deffecientcies earlier, the dialogue system is sort of similar to mass effect, instead of picking what you are going to say, you instead pick an 'approach' such as being suave, joking, aggressive, etc. However, you don't know HOW WELL or how MUCH Micheal is going to go.  Cutting to the chase, Michael is ♥♥♥♥ing terrible at jokes, and is extremely violent and sadistic when given the chance.  To make things worse, being successful against certain NPCS tends to just mean picking one approach and staying with it instead of responding appropriately in a fluid converstational matter.  Of course, since it's an obsidian game, it's filled with a few glitches and probably missing 20% content.All these terrible things being said about the game, it's definitely worth your time, there's some great scenes, and a couple of interesting characters, and some decent customization for your very own secret agent.

												8.5/10+ nice presentation overall, good character models, some bad textures though, could use more detail in the environment, the art is fine though+ gameplay is very interesting overall, with great variety, from stealth to fps, with some high tech tools depending on how you choose to play it+ excellent writing, some fantastic dialogues, very deep dialogue tree, as you expect from one of the companies that have mastered it (obsidian)+ conspiracy story, a bit generic , but it is presented in a realistic way, some very nice side missions that you get to choose as well+ good upgrade system, weapons variety etc- rough technically, mediore animations, generic fps mechanics, generic melee mechanics, fighting certainly needed a polish- could last longer (especially if you go all the way to the main story without caring for the side missions it is really short)- nothing else, it could be a masterpiece if they gave more time to its production, highly recommended though especially to those bored of all the fantasy rpg games out there

												One of the most under rated games!  Pros:* It's a fantastic RPG experience: good mix between action, stealth and RPG. * The storyline and characters are awesome. * All your decisions (kill civilians, leave a boss alive, etc.) have real consequence.* Like any RPG, you have to choose your skill, buy/sell weapons, objects, ammo, etc.* You can play each mission like Rambo, or Sam Fischer or a mix of them (kill only enemies).* Good replayability (Kill Them All, save the civilians, flirt with all the girls, etc.)Cons:* Some lag if you move your mouse too quickly* Sega have abandoned the seriesBuy it, buy it now :p

												First I thought, oh hey, a bargain for 2 Euros.Then I started the game... and suddenly lost 6 hours of my life before I realized that it is well past midnight.This game is pure awesome. It delivers on presentation, story, sound only sometimes I wish I could fiddle with the mouse sensitivity for sniping. The effects of your in-game decisions are very visible in the storyline and so far, it looks as if there is no right or wrong choice... you just play like you want to play. If I had to, I would describe this game like a playable version of a James Bond movie who had a love child with the Burn Notice TV series.As long as it is 90% off, BUY IT! No excuses! This game is well worth the money and I would pay 40 bucks and consider it money well spent. The last time I had so much fun was with Mass Effect 1 and 2.

content:
Posted: September 24, 2011
												Alpha protocol's story is possibly one of the best I've seen when it comes to spy games/movies.It's complex,but not confusing, rewarding multiple playthroughs.The dialogue also comes through,as it's well written and it's mass effect-esque dialogue branch keeps multiple playthroughs fresh.Unfortunatelly,it also has the same problem as Mass Effect,as some of the dialogue choices you make might actually mislead you and have unintended results(like negatively affecting your stance with a character).As usual in an Obsidian game,it also suffers from technical problems,raging from slowdowns on certain machines to enemies not loading on a quick-load.The gameplay also suffers from slight imbalances,with some bossfights being resistant to weapons/skills you might have selected.If it's going for cheap,do get the game.The story alone is worth it!Note:DRM was removed on patch 1.1 so you don't need to worry about install limits anymore.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 26, 2016
												Alpha Protocol is one of the most responsive RPGs I have ever played. Even as the overall plot stays on course to take you through much the same set of levels, characters and circumstances react to your actions in ways you may not even appreciate without a second playthrough. Alpha Protocol's story isn't even that interesting from a wide perspective, honestly - what makes this game amazing is all the work Obsidian put into its execution, shaping a story whose interactivity blows so many other games out of the water.Many of the mechanics are roughly executed or even just ill-conceived, for which Alpha Protocol has been deservedly criticized. Even at release it was not a very good shooter or a very good stealth game, and those parts have certainly not improved with age. But at the end of the day, solid execution on the narrative end keeps things interesting and helps make the game more than just the sum of its parts.If you like branching narrative in your action RPGs, then you need to see what an amazing job this game does in both making its narrative threads reactive and in tying them all together. After playing Alpha Protocol, I always wish more games were like it.

content:
Posted: November 26, 2013
												Alpha Protocol is a bipolar title. If strictly estimated on the gameplay, you can not overlook the serious problems of balance in terms of character development (there are combinations that literally break the game in the later stages), while the stealth sessions and the AI ​​deficit are to be reviewed completely. However, assessed on the RPG side, the game is surprising for the vastness of the choices allowed, not only with regard to the growth of our pg and for the approach to missions, but it will also be possible to completely change the outcome of the events and characters, so that every game will never be the same as another. The dialogue system is as it should be in the last Bioware titles, especially if you wanted to bet on cinematograficity: there is a wheel, not the phrases severed but with the attitude to be taken, which obviously work differently depending dell'interlocutor, plus the ability to gather information to exploit. Everything is in time, a solution that, if at the beginning can be confusing, serves well to remain vigilant of the player and the pace of the narrative.Definitely recommended to all lovers of spy stories, as long as you close an eye on the technical side.

Want to run around the whole time shooting ♥♥♥♥ers in the face with a shotgun? Whatever man do what you want. But a little side note, the combat mechanics isn't exactly straightforward. In this sense it's more like an rpg. When you shoot a guy, the game calculates hit percentages and crits and♥♥♥♥♥♥like that. So when you line up your scoped pistol to the face of a guy three feet away from you who miraculously hasn't seen you yet, point it straight between that ♥♥♥♥ing dudes eyes, you pull the trigger...then somehow find out you missed and the dude has just stopped being blind long enough to riddle your♥♥♥♥♥with bullets. Yeah well, that's the game telling you to go ♥♥♥♥ yourself. So just keep that in mind.But really the best part of the game is talking to people. Through your super spy social skills, you can choose things like whether or not you want to kill a guy. Or if you want to be an ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, then be an ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. Seriously you choose how you want to behave or make important story decisions through dialogue. Also if you're super suave (or not) you could ♥♥♥♥ most of the chicks in this game. I myself ♥♥♥♥ed two chicks, however I probably could have had sex with another one, but I turned her down because I didn't think it was fair to the others. I'll check that out in my next playthough though.With that all being said, this game can be a fun game. However, the frustrating part comes into play with this games glitches. I've probably replayed levels over and over more than I should have because of these glitches. Sometimes after dying and starting at a checkpoint, it seems that every guard decides to just get up and ♥♥♥♥ing leave, with me running around not knowing what to do because every single guard decided to go on a lunch break. There are other random glitches that you will undoubtedly encounter during your time as America's super awesome spy.But I must say that however glitchy this game can be, it is not as bad as I was lead to believe before I bought it. Is this game fun? Yes. Is it frustrating? Yes. Is it more frustrating than fun? No. Is it worth 15 bucks? Maybe, but definitely worth 10 bucks. So I recommend you buying this game on sale at 10 bucks or under. Now excuse me while I replay this game and try to have sex with all three chicks.I nominated this game for "The Villian In Most Need Of A Hug" Award. Because it needs a hug...and a sequel.

content:
Posted: January 7, 2014
												This game frequently gets compared to the famous Mass Effect Series. To be honest though, all the two have in common are the graphic engine, the 3rd person view and the fact, that you as a player get to choose the direction of your ingame conversations. Still, the comparison can be made in order to help people decide, if this game might be for them, or not. While Mass Effect is a lot more RPG (especially the first game) as it lets you wander around, talk to npcs and aquire quests, Alpha Protocol is a bit more linear in its storytelling, since only the order in which you complete your missions and the order of your missionhubs can be determined by the player. The missions itself are pretty action-oriented, even though you might want to take a stealthy approach from time to time in order to take out a few enemies without being noticed or to move into a more favorable position for your assault. It is possible to put lots of talent points into being 'stealthy' and playing almost exclusively like this, but it has to be said that the game is by no means a Splinter Cell and some direct confrontation especially during the last stages of the game is unavoidable. Mission locations are quite diversified, while the level design itself is very linear. During your missions you'll receive radio support by your 'handler', who updates you with the latest mission relevant information. In addition, you'll frequently encounter locked doors and password protected computers, which you'll be able to open or hack by beating one of the increasingly difficult mini-games. The graphics are decent, I especially liked the facial textures of the characters and the depth of field effects. The voice-acting is great, the writing is excellent, as it often offers you funny witty responses in dialogues and also features your expected conspiracy theories and the like. Another note on the subject of dialogue choices in this game: unlike Mass Effect, where you get to choose the exact response you want to give and have unlimited time in deciding on which one it is going to be, you can only choose the general tone and direction of your answer in Alpha Protocol, while at the same time being forced to make this decision within a few seconds. Responses include 'professional', 'threatening', 'suave', 'flirtatious' or a certain subject you want to touch upon. While initially this system felt irritating, once you get used to it, it feels rather dynamic and natural, since there are no pauses during dialogues and you are forced to make decisions on the fly. Decisions in this game have a real impact on the main plot aswell, as often you'll have to make meaningful choices between making allies or enemies, life and death or something of similar weight. Characters react differently to your approach during conversations, and since the game keeps track of your standing with each character, I often find myself reading up on a character's personal files before talking to them in order to get a better understanding of what said npc might react most positively to.So what can you expect from this game? Solid, but not spectacular 3rd person shooter gameplay in a spy setting with some stealth elemtents and gadgets, engaging cutscenes and conversations with meaningful decisionmaking wrapped in a rather complex storyline. Less depth than Mass Effect, less playtime and less production value - but by no means a bad game. The only thing the game really lacks because of this are the big, breathtaking moments. Nonetheless, Alpha Protocol has some pretty memorable scenes (including hook-ups, you perv!) and I am quite satisfied with my first playthrough. Especially if you like the spy-setting, want something tight and less drawn out and prefer a more action-oriented approach to the genre, Alpha Protocol is a must-have.

content:
Posted: November 26, 2016
												Alpha Protocol is one of the most responsive RPGs I have ever played. Even as the overall plot stays on course to take you through much the same set of levels, characters and circumstances react to your actions in ways you may not even appreciate without a second playthrough. Alpha Protocol's story isn't even that interesting from a wide perspective, honestly - what makes this game amazing is all the work Obsidian put into its execution, shaping a story whose interactivity blows so many other games out of the water.Many of the mechanics are roughly executed or even just ill-conceived, for which Alpha Protocol has been deservedly criticized. Even at release it was not a very good shooter or a very good stealth game, and those parts have certainly not improved with age. But at the end of the day, solid execution on the narrative end keeps things interesting and helps make the game more than just the sum of its parts.If you like branching narrative in your action RPGs, then you need to see what an amazing job this game does in both making its narrative threads reactive and in tying them all together. After playing Alpha Protocol, I always wish more games were like it.

content:
Posted: November 26, 2013
												Alpha Protocol is a bipolar title. If strictly estimated on the gameplay, you can not overlook the serious problems of balance in terms of character development (there are combinations that literally break the game in the later stages), while the stealth sessions and the AI ​​deficit are to be reviewed completely. However, assessed on the RPG side, the game is surprising for the vastness of the choices allowed, not only with regard to the growth of our pg and for the approach to missions, but it will also be possible to completely change the outcome of the events and characters, so that every game will never be the same as another. The dialogue system is as it should be in the last Bioware titles, especially if you wanted to bet on cinematograficity: there is a wheel, not the phrases severed but with the attitude to be taken, which obviously work differently depending dell'interlocutor, plus the ability to gather information to exploit. Everything is in time, a solution that, if at the beginning can be confusing, serves well to remain vigilant of the player and the pace of the narrative.Definitely recommended to all lovers of spy stories, as long as you close an eye on the technical side.

												Dont trust the reviews. This game is very overlooked because people were expecting a third person shooter aka Mass Effect and got dissapointed. This game is a RPG first and a TPS second. If you keep that in mind, and raise your skills accordingly... to your weapons + playstyle then you will enjoy this game. This game has high replay value and a very dynamic story that changes through each playthrough. It's very hard to get the same ending/middle if you take different approaches. If your looking for a game that will suck you into its world and give you freedom of choice, this would be your game.

content:
Posted: February 1, 2011
												Modern day Mass Effect clone by the clone studio with the worst QA staff in the world, Obsidian. Very linear with typical Bioware-esque "go to three places for three quests and then on-rails for the last mission" game structure. Mostly boring characters... The few interesting characters are either useless (Beck) or are only around for two scenes and then limited to being mentioned in convos (Sis). Combat is mostly cover based shooting but gets frustrating from enemies killing you while behind cover ("realistic" cover with bullets going through broken concrete and such). Unreliable weapon damage, for both you and your enemies, results in random encounters which dump you back to the last checkpoint (no quicksaving or save anywhere options, thanks consoles) from an AI SMG spraying you and getting 5 lucky headshots in a row. Besides all the problems with it I was able to have a fun yet overly frustrating time with this Deus Ex-esque modern day spy thriller and recommend picking it up.

content:
Posted: January 1
												This is a great game. Just finished it.Disclaimer,  there are some annoying glitches and bugs here and there but once you get used to the weapon aiming and the hand to hand combat it's more than tolerable. If you can see past some of the minor flaws, you'll find one of the best video game stories I have ever played. Not quite the character development of Mass Effect but a great secret agent story. The dialogue, story, and voice acting are excellent. The moral and ethical choices are really satisfying. If you can crank up the resolution the graphics still look pretty good. None of the writing or voice acting were filler. All the emails, dossiers, and newscasts are crucial to the plot and game play, and quite funny at times. You really do have to build a rapport with characters and be tactful with the ladies to get anywhere. Make sure you go for the "Ladies Man" acheivement. ;) One of the things I found dissappointing was even on a mission with patience and perfect stealth you still have to fight your way out as part of the story. Overall, if you like a Jack Ryan, Jack Bauer, ripped from the headlines kind of story, you'll really enjoy this. The newscasts and politcal scenarios could have easily been written in the last couple months and don't feel dated at all. Truly a hidden gem, well worth it even if not on sale, just make sure you finish it, it's worth the time. I just hope they make a sequel. Given that there's no Metal Gear or Splinter Cell games in the pipeline that I know of, I think this is an underserved market right now. Too much fantasy needs a little bit of reality. Even if it's the Mission Impossible, Jason Bourne, Homeland imaginary kind of reality.

number of helpful: 20 of 40 people (50%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 9, 2015
TLDR VERDICTOverall, I can’t really objectively recommend Alpha Protocol. It has a wonderful premise that works well in some places, but ultimately fails in a lot more. If you value story over gameplay and you’re in the mood for a good espionage story, then buy this game on sale and breeze through it on easy to avoid frustration. If you’re looking for a good overall stealth action experience, then you won’t really find one here. Here’s hoping Obsidian actually get the time and resources to try a game like this again with a lot more polish.FULL REVIEW BELOW“The only thing I can say for sure, Mike, this business will change you.” – Yancy WestridgeMike Thorton is the newest recruit in for the top secret US government agency known as Alpha Protocol. His first assignment for the agency seems to be stopping a standard terrorist plot, which rapidly evolves into a globe-trotting conspiracy hunt. This review is written from the perspective of a fan of stealth action games with an emphasis on multiple approaches. Also a fan of story driven RPGs.GAMEPLAY AND DESIGNAlpha Protocol’s gameplay is not its best asset. The level designs are largely linear stealth action arenas that don’t offer a lot of room for natural exploration or experimentation. There sometimes are hidden rooms that offer loot or alternate routes, but they are few and far between. If you want accurate expectations, you need to dismiss the notion that Alpha Protocol can be played as a pure stealth game from start to finish. Despite the tagline “the espionage RPG”, there are missions clearly designed for stealth, combat and mixtures of the two. If you try to employ combat in a stealth section or stealth in a combat section you’re just going to get frustrated. The problem is that game doesn’t exactly make clear what’s coming, requiring the player to employ some forethought, versatility and adaptability. It sounds neat, but can get frustrating when you show up in full combat gear to a stealth mission or vice versa.The combat and stealth mechanics are a mixed bag. It employs are variation on Deus Ex 1s gunplay, where you basically can’t aim at all until you put enough points into that guns skill. It’s sounds cool, but at the end you basically end up with these horribly over-powered cooldown based weapon abilities that can 1 or 2 shot bosses. The bosses are another negative point for the game. A few of them can be beaten with stealth, but most of them are bullet sponges that you have to take on directly. It reminds me of a similar frustration I had in Deus Ex: Human Revolution, where you would manage your inventory and skills for one playstyle, only to run into a boss that demands another. These inconsistent difficulty spikes are irritatingly prevalent throughout the whole game. Sometimes it seems like the AI has a field of view of 45 degrees in front of them and sometimes it’s like they have eyes on the backs of their heads. The obstacles that enemies can and can’t see through are also inconsistent. The combat AI is smart enough, taking cover and using grenades etc. The stealth AI is less so. They like to stick to predictable paths, can’t hear anything and bodies can’t be moved so they hardly ever spot them.The character progression system is very Mass Effect 1-esque. There are skills that are weapon based and the rest help with other aspects of the game (stealth, hacking etc.). Points can award you with passive abilities and active abilities. The progression starts pretty steady, but as mentioned before, by the end if you specialised correctly you can run around invisible, one shotting everything. Not an exaggeration.STORY AND NARRATIVEThe story and the way Alpha Protocol handles conversations is easily my favourite aspect of it. The conversation options are timed and almost always boil down to 3 responses. You can be a James Bond style suave guy; an Agent 47 professional guy; or just an all-out aggressive♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥nozzle. Different characters will respond to different tones accordingly and this can affect how much they like or dislike you. You can use this to your advantage, making your handlers and potential assets like you for information and perks and♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥off enemies to make them easier to beat. The game provides loads of dossiers with two distinct categories: individuals and organisations. Organisation dossiers are pretty straight forward, and are mostly used to give you a rundown of opposition tactics. Individual dossiers are more interesting, as you can exploit the information in them to find out what sort of responses people would like/dislike and times use secret facts in a conversation which have varying special results. For example, you can actually use dossier information in conversations to make two bosses turn on each other later making the fight a breeze. Of course, these options only appear if you actually read the dossiers, which feels pretty damn cool for a spy game.The story itself is structured pretty similarly to your standard Deus Ex game. You have a straightforward prologue that introduces you to the world and then spans into a globetrotting conspiracy hunt. The game does a good job of conveying the feeling of unravelling the plot as you progress, discovering (or even predicting) plot twists as they are thrown at you. There are plenty of choices in the game that are all very morally ambiguous and open-ended in true Obsidian fashion. The factions you side with and♥♥♥♥♥♥off can have fairly significant effects on the rest of the game both during gameplay and in the story. You can try to be good or evil, but most choices boil down to picking between two awful things, which is great.The actual voice acting in this game is surprisingly not half bad for the most part. This is surprising, considering the rough patches the rest of the game has. Aside from a few specific moments, the voice acting holds up for the most part.GRAPHICS AND PERFORMANCEAlpha Protocol is a rough looking game, even for its time (2010). The character models and animations are pretty terrible, texture work is very mediocre, and relying on lighting and shadow effects to stay hidden will almost always backfire. The animations in general are pretty laughable. This especially stands out when patrolling enemies freak out for a second when changing direction. The martial arts moves look pretty janky as well. A very average looking game, not dated enough to deter me, but not exactly anything to marvel at either.Performance-wise, Alpha Protocol is an Obsidian game. What this usually means, is there are a lot of bugs, cut content and a few performance hitches. Alpha Protocol is not a stranger to any of these issues. As mentioned before, the AI is horribly inconsistent, a lot of missions like to bug out when reloading checkpoints (which are designed terribly, no manual saves), and you get punished for breaking stealth or rules of engagement when you know you didn’t. The bugs and technical problems combined with the poor gameplay mechanics make a very frustrating pile of game to get through the gems for the story content, which is a damn shame because those gems can be brilliant at times.

content:
Posted: February 25
												Ok, where to start?Story: The game forgets your decisions, regularly, and ♥♥♥♥s you up during the final mission for it. If you want to do a through and through American agent playthrough and perform non-lethal attacks on every enemy through the whole game, at the very end you will be randomly accused of killing American agents and have the "'merica" ending locked out.Also in the final mission, despite never interacting with a certain character who I had no intentions of harming through the entire game, I'm looking for the room where I can rescue them, then, bam! Checkpoint pops up, overrides my save, and informs me that I shot them. Not that someone else did, I am told by another character, that I was in a conversation with this person, and shot them. Locking me out of another ending...Mechanics:The ability UI is super clunky, pressing Z, X and C to bring up three different menu's for ammo types, abilities and equipment (Grenades, Sound generators etc.) However, when you bring up one of these menu's there's like a 2 second pause where you can't do anything (Dispite my high end computer), and once that's over you have to click the thing 7-8 times before you actually select it. Even worse, if you bring up the wrong menu, you can't just press the correct key and open the other menu, you either have to close the current menu and open a new one, or press these *TINY* little arrows that scroll though the menu's.As for the weapons. Use the pistol. It has an ability that let's you instantly line up 6 headshots that automatically crit and usually kill any soldier you have LoS too. The assault rifle is the most innaccurate thing in the world unless you point it at the same spot for 4 seconds (1.5 seconds if you pump ALL your level-up points into it). The SMG's will never hit anything and the shotgun causes too much collateral and just doesn't seem to do much in the way of damage.Saving. You literally can't. There's a checkpoint system, you can make it remember your checkpoints, but they're usually far-ish apart, and god forbid you make a bad decision in an important conversation, (Or a flatout the wrong one, sometimes you're given less then a second to make a choice) as after almost every single one is a checkpoint, and the game has an awful habit of putting important conversations up to half an hours of gameplay away from the last safehouse, or fifteen minutes if you force the game to remember EVERY checkpoint. (Perhaps intentionally, make you live with your decision? Sucks for player choise I guess...) I guess the game is simply trying to encourage replayability so you can play through to make the disicions you wish you made last time? But I dunno about everyone else, but I sat through a second 60 hours of Mass Effect so I could play a different character, not the same one with a little less schitzophrenia...

number of helpful: 5 of 11 people (45%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 28, 2014
												Don't bother with this. I'd heard it was pretty poor, but since it was cheap I decided to give it a go due to it's interesting spy espionage theme. Basically everything is just badly executed. Stealth is too easy due to the braindead AI who will sit and stare at you for about 10 seconds before walking off. Combat is just boring because of it's generic structure and fairly odd aiming system. You can basically get around most of the areas with the standard grunt enemy through bugs and glitches - I know I did. Then you go up against a boss. These are pretty unfair and the only way you'll win is by hiding behind cover, slowly picking off each of the boss's goons and then shooting the boss in the face for about 20 minutes until their stupidly large health bar is empty. The only thing this game really has going for it is it's storytelling, with all that choices and branching stuff, ya know what I mean? It was alright I guess, but since all the characters are cardboard cutouts of generic spy movie stereotypes I found it hard to be invested in the story at all. So yeah, don't bother with this game, unless you're willing to devote some time into it. Personally, I couldn't be bothered to play more than 4 hours because it just had too many floors for my taste. However, I can appreciate why people do defend this game.

number of helpful: 4 of 9 people (44%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 25, 2014
												Overall score: 5/10The game isn´t that bad, in fact it seems really awesome at the beginning. It feels like a Mass Effect 2 with better controls, more content and more interaction possibilities. At the beginning, that is.As soon as you get into your HQ and start doing missions, the game becomes extremely boring because its very repetitive.Here a summary of the first two hours:Arrive in HQ, look around and explore the rooms in your HQ, buy stuff for your inventory/gear, go into a mission in mid east, kill bad guys, return to HQ, buy stuff for your inventory, go into mission in mid east, kill bad guys, return to HQ, ...and so on.After two hours I was fed up with the game, and uninstalled it.The teammates seemed rather dull and boring, I didnt feel any obligation or interest to listen to the stuff they wanted to tell me, so I just tl;dr´d 75% of the conversations as soon as I noticed that it was going to be a boring dialogue.The many ways to kill or not kill and move or sneak around the maps are there, but not necessary nor effective. There hasnt been a single scenario where sneaking around the whole map and silently killing enemies would have been as efficient as just going full Rambo-mode on them.The weapons feel weird. Extremely inaccurate even when you crouch and aim down the sights. So I mostly took them out with stationed MGs.Overall... meh. Its kind of okay, but it gets boring very quickly.

number of helpful: 4 of 9 people (44%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 30, 2014
												I had such high hopes for this game, I don't know why. Uninspired and cumbersome design, annoying glitches and characters that range from the dull to downright offensive make this game a chore to play. The fact that players need to keep their reticules perfectly still for several agonizing seconds to gain accuracy while the opponents bob and weave through cover is frustrating. The decision to force players to specialize and force them into cookie cutter situations anyway is pants-crappingly ♥♥♥♥♥♥, because it forces the player to completely respec their stealth specialist into an assault trooper every time a boss rolls around. Sticky cover ruins the gunfights. The writing suggests a mind-numbingly simple view of world politics where the question whether the ends justify the means doesn't even come up. The illusion of choice basically comes down to what kind of ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ you want to be. The plot doesn't connect to any sense of impact or urgency, because characters run a gamut of paperthin stereotypes. Women in particular seem to have little depth, with boosting the male player's ego as their main function. A comparison with old school Bond movies is apt, except that Alpha Protocol seems to take itself more seriously. maybe it's that AP takes place in a realistic setting, but I can't shake the thought that protagonist Mike Thornton is a sociopath no matter how you play him. I tried to play him as a decent human being but the game just doesn't allow that. Some of the dialogue options are openly misogynistic, despite being labeled 'joking'. If that is how the writers think, then that's ♥♥♥♥ed up. Even at a discount, this was a mistake to buy.

content:
Posted: April 11
												Worth the 4$ I paid for it when it was on sale. Never worth 15$.This game tries to heavily imitate Splinter Cell with additional elements of The Witcher (branching story, team-building).What I enjoyed:- decisions affect the future, even something as simple as those during training runs in the beginning- different attitudes affect different teammates differenty, so one must understand their temper- the story branches out based on previous actions and there are tons of scenes for all kinds of combinations of previous actions, the more I play the better it getsWhat I hated:- stealth mechanics: some of the worst in a stealth game- shooting: clunky, unnatural and has crippling timed functions. too many features, none work great.- melee: actually not bad, especially with additional skills- "hacking" minigames are stipid, especially number-matching- saving: no quicksaves, only savepoints which is sickening- story: your average spy story with lots of twists but unfortunately often very naive- getting accustomed: it took me an hour or two to get used to how bad the above-mentioned things areIt's like an early beta version of a game that was never finished or polished. It's an ok game to kill a little time if it's on sale.

content:
Posted: November 13, 2016
												I have to say, I really wanted to like this game.There certainly are a lot of compelling, well done mechanics of the game, but they don't seem to flow together very well.The combat is incredibly repetitve, the cover and aiming systems are occasionally finnicky and annoying. My biggest concern with combat is the viewport. The field of view makes it very difficult to scan the area and locate all of the enemies. Meanwhile, the all know your exact location if there is an alarm going off. Part of a stealth game is the ability to have information about your environment and the enemy, and I can't tell you how many times I set off an alarm because I couldn't see a guard walking around a corner as I climbed some stairs. The story was somewhat derivative, but the choices effects on the storyline were very well done. That said, the dialogue system feels a bit clunky. First of all, you usually have to make your decision before the other person has even finished talking, so it doesn't feel like you're responding, but rather choosing a stance before you know what's happening. There is also a perk you get for choosing one of each stance in a conversation. Interestingly, the left, top, and right choices seem to be hard coded to a type,  there are a few times where the three options are not related to a personality but are just collecting various intel about the upcoming mission, but you can still get the perk that way. There are also many characters who show up once and seem super important and then never have any effect on the story.Lastly, the main character's writing/voiceacting is AWFUL. I can't stress enough how forced all of his lines were and how his tone failed to fit the moment. Very often I regretted some of my dialogue choices not because of what they were but because of how dull the character was saying them. When you choose to execute Nasri in Saudi Arabia, Mike says, in such a dull voice "Ooops, looks like the comm line is dead" or something equally stupid. This is the first time I realized how bad the voice acting was.

Posted: November 27, 2014
												I really wanted to like this game, as a Modern Espionage action RPG it fills a niche that no other game before or since has tried to. But the controls are so broken and the combat mechanics so terrible that I simply could not.The story is compelling, the game's concept is interesting, but the execution falls flat.The hacking mini-game, the mastering of which is critical to the game, is nearly impossible to do with the keyboard and mouse combo; fortunately this game does support gamepads as clearly this game was designed for consoles and the PC port was a sloppy after thought.Every now and then I look for mods for this game, something to un-♥♥♥♥ the gameplay, but I have yet to find anything that fixes the gameplay. Which is a damn shame: the first mission really drew me in to this game's story, but Alpha Protocol's broken game mechanics pushed me right back out.

content:
Posted: April 21
												This is one of those games I've begged Steam support to wipe from my account history. I'm not satisfied with just ticking the "hidden" box - I have to destroy any record I ever played it. Alpha Protocol is really lame. It's like distilled lame. It's like watching Marvel: Agents of Shield or something on TV, and breaking down how lame and hokey it is and incorporating those elements into a game.  The lifeblood of Alpha Protocol, your character Michael Thorton, BLOWS. He sucks as a martial arts expert. He sucks as an infiltrator. He sucks as a John Woo ™ gunslinger. He's not charming, or intimidating, or insightful. His agent loadout looks like the "My First Spy" playsets you see at the dollar store. His weapons handle like popguns. His outfits look like Halloween costumes. Basically, this game is so singularly terrible at fulfilling the power fantasy of being a worldclass secret agent, it seems like it could only exist by way of a genie who would grant your wish for a spy RPG and vindictively make it the worst spy RPG possible. This flabby, childish, uninteresting mess, designed to put you off spy-related media for the rest of your life.Sound design is the definition of average. 5/10. Controls are there. 4/10. Gameplay is a whopping 3/10. Art direction is like a bad comic book. Like the ones made by Sears to teach their employees how important loss prevention is. 2/10. Story "exists". 2/10. Supporting characters? They almost exist. 1/10. Michael Thorton is a well earned 0. Really, it's an accomplishment.Seriously, Steam, please. I will pay you to take this game off my history.

content:
Posted: November 26, 2014
												Shooting is functional (frankly I’m no expert on the matter, as far as I’m concerned “You point at people and they die” is the pinnacle of the shooter experience), but the RPG elements are really well thought, you can feel your character becoming progressively more powerful over time, maybe slightly OP. The plot is… Somewhat of a mess. There’s a lot of different secret agencies making their moves in the background, and it might be difficult to wrap your head around at first, especially since certain crucial info is only unlocked through different decisions along the way. BUT, the plot also adapts really well to the decisions you make along the way, and your play style. It feels like your actions carry weight, and the plot develops accordingly. While the final level plays the same, your character might have an entirely different motivation, and the final boss might be entirely different people. It adds to the replayabitliy, and I think the game truly shines only on the second play through. Overall, I recommend Alpha Protocol. It offers a nice blend of stealth and shooter, and the RPG elements complement either playstyle.

content:
Posted: April 16, 2014
												Recommended but ,read some details below.Overall, this game looks like if it was made ten years ago.Somewhat an RPG, 3rd person action and stealth game, which sounds really interesting, right?.In the ballpark of splinter cell.In the positive side, story is interesting and deep. Missions are variated. Each dialogue has several alternative attitudes to answer, which directly impacts in relationships with main characters. Black Market to personalize your equipment and to gather some info, is also a good thing.It's somewhat similar to early Splinter Cell games, including door lock cracking, digital pannels, PC and survilance cameras control.So, the overall design of the game is interesting enough.In the negative side, controls are a tad sloppy and, particularly, camera (or head) rotation. Enemies IA lacks the I, they suddenly attack you (even if you are stealthing and they are far away) or, they ignore you while killing one enemy beside other. That's weird and, probably the two things that rest points to a game that, otherwise, would be a great one.Difficulty is easy, in normal mode. It's really difficult to dead during fights. Stealth has not so much importance. You end killing everybody, at the end.But the few bosss are really hard to bate.Game has hours of playing so, you will be entertained for a while.The balance in relationships between your character and other main characters is difficult to achieve and, depends on which attitude you are selecting for each conversation chunk. This helps to increase that sensation that you  don't know who to trust and, who are the good boys.

content:
Posted: July 27, 2015
												An overwrought, undercooked spy action RPG choose your own adventure. Written by people who have absolutely no idea how real human beings talk but like to dazzle you with constant back and forth half answers so you get confused and think you're watching clever people joust verbally.Still worth trucking through the lack of polish and the dour writing because, hey, when you're trying so, SO hard to be clever, you actually end up sometimes being clever despite yourself. The bosses are more interesting than you'd expect in a Syphon Filter-esque TPS baked with RPG. The array of characters each with different personalities and motivations and schemes to keep straight is dizzying and you are constantly making friends, enemies, and choices. The plot itself may be limp and boring but the way you navigate is far more interesting than anything that actually happens.I could count the memorable scenes in this game on one hand, and the memorable lines of dialogue with the remaining fingers, but the ones that stick out are definitely interesting.

												A pretty good spy action RPG by the legends themselves, Obsidian. Strangely, opinions on this game differ, with most media outlets despising it, while the typical unaffiliated reviewer, such as myself, finding it worth of praise. number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 9, 2014
												When I got the game from a bundle, I was not expecting much from it and thought it would be a medicore game. Oh god, I was so wrong and I ain't even complaining about it. AP is a TPS-RPG hybrid like Mass Effect series but unlike ME it takes place in today's world. It leaves us to take control of a spy and go on missions all across the world. If I told anything about the story I'd probably spoil something unintentionall so I'll just leave pros and consPros:-Dialogue system is pretty nice and gives you a few seconds to make your choice, makes it more realistic IMO-The game lets you decide entirely how you're gonna play it. You can be a stealth assassin and catch people unaware, go Rambo against an army, run to people and punch them to death etc etc-Weapon/armor variety and upgrades are nice and enables you to custimize your weapons/armor to suit your playstyle-Can be finished multiple times to see all parts of story(long playability time)-Great story filled with betrayals, treasons, revenge, love and lots of interesting stuff-Things like lockpicking and bypassing stays enjoyable through your playthtrough-Watching the news and hearing whatever you've done on the broadcast is a fun detail, and also everything you do on a mission effects the(close or far) future onesCons:-Hacking. Honestly it is so stressing and tiring that I found myself wishing it didn't exist. It was fun in the first 2-3 time but having it as the most frequent minigame and making it harder and harder just killed the magic.-Camera can be a bit messy sometimes.-Some people say they encountered many bugs on internet but throughout my playththrough I only faced literally 2 bugs-Sometimes guns require too much accuracy(stat). Eventhough you point your gun to the other person's head and wait for it to be in critical state it may not even leave a scratch on them-AI can screw hard during combats-Skills make the game too easy(trying to play it without skills is fun though but challanging)That's all I can say, I guess. I think this game is criminally underrated and even though I got it from a bundle, I'd happily pay the original price to play it. P.S: I reccomend playing the game as stealth assassin as it is more fun and AI is much better during the stealth times

content:
Posted: June 28, 2015
												Oh damn you Obsidian for the hate/love relationship I have with your games.49% of me wants to recommend this game and 51% not to. I will do the democratic thing and not recommend it, but I will list some of the pros and cons which constitute these numbers below:Pros - why 49% of me would recommend it- Well written story, characters, dialogue- It really manages to make you feel like a spy most of the times- It has some really interesting and original ideas- It has some great RPG mechanics- You should play it at least to see that Obsidian can come up with some cool stuffCons- why 51% of me would not recommend it- Buggy- Gameplay is terrible... in an age of third person shooters... Obsidian failed to pull off decent basic 3rd person shooter mechanics- Mechanics are not really balanced- Some loose ends... aka you don't see the consequences of some of your decisions- I found the ending to be really badAll in all, if you are curious, you should definitelly pick it up for a sale. At the very least it might help Obidian hire some programmers and designers who can actually design a game around what I think are some very cool ideas they have. You can't make a good game with just good writing tho'.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: May 31, 2013
												Before Alpha Protocol, I didn't know Obsidian Entertainment existed. I didn't know they developed Star Wars: Knights of the Old Republic II, I didn't know they made Fallout: New Vegas, and I didn't know they created the Neverwinter Nights series. Heck, it wasn't until my second playthrough of Alpha Protcol almost half a year later that I discovered how much I really, really like this game.Obsidian Entertainment is best known for being the developer other developers hand their franchises to when they hit a creative rut. Bioware handed them Knights of the Old Republic, and Bethesda handed them Fallout. In both cases, Obsidian took those franchises and surpassed the original games.Alpha Protocol, while technically released after Fallout: New Vegas, could be seen as Obsidian's first original IP since Neverwinter Nights, and boy is it an ambitious one. Alpha Protocol is an action-y/stealth-y/gadget-y/spy-y with aspirations to being everything that Mass Effect promised to be. It plays like a movie, emphasizes player choice, and offers a diverse number of playstyles.It comes within micrometers of being one of my favorite games. It's so close to being perfect that I can almost smell it. With some tweaking, the stealth could be great, the shooting fun, and the storyline fascinating. Unfortunately, small things muck up the gameplay. Stealth is hampered by the lack of attention the boss battles pay to it, alongside inconsistent NPC fields of view. The story is... well, while it's very nicely presented, it tends to be an incomprehensible mess. I didn't have much of an idea what was going on until my second playthrough.But despite the flaws, Alpha Protocol is very, very good. For all its flaws, it's an ambitious game, and it earns an easy recommendation from me.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 10
												Alpha Protocol is a polarizing game, and rightly so. It's janky, not quite balanced, and has some miserably bad voice acting. It's also one of my favorite games of all time. Have I gone crazy? Well...To begin with, there are over a dozen different types of items to find, customize, and use in missions. Nearly everything in the game that you can equip can be upgraded, and all of the upgrading is optional. Importantly, there's no one item or item type that you must use to progress. You could finish the entire main storyline with your starting guns and punch the vast majority of hostiles with your fists, which can be upgraded. And your character's durability can be upgraded in much the same way, which is important if you want to start a bunch of boxing matches with armed gaurds. You can play stealthily, loudly, loudly like a fox (trick the guards into activating an alarm panel that's rigged up with a sticky grenade, for example), or any combination of approaches that suits your playstyle. The difficulty comes from the enemies and hazards directly, and not from the all too common "everything-proof shield" that most developers of action games lazily rely on.The level design is excellent, for the most part. You'll rarely be completely lost, guard placement is optimal, items aren't too densely packed to be challenging, nor too sparse, and turrets and the like aren't common enough to be infuriating, but not so rare as to make a technology-focused build less powerful than the others. Your decisions in previous missions, and in the sequences between them, will even open some paths and block others, but it isn't overdone enough to become tedious. And it's quite rare to be without cover and alternate paths simultaneously.The levelling system is quite good, for my tastes, but will certainly bother others. If you focus on putting all your points into a skill, your character will become quite overpowered in that skill by the end of the game. Stealth skill will eventually give you a cloak on a cooldown, pistols can be aimed in slow motion and fired cartoonishly rapidly, shotguns are eventually able to keep bosses almost permanently knocked down, and so on. On the one hand, this means that the skill points you spend are going somewhere useful, regadless of what you prefer to level up. On the other hand, if you're looking for something brutally difficult, or even realistically difficult to overcome, you won't be satisfied by Alpha Protocol. By the end of the game you're basically a superhero fighting large hordes of well-armed goons and the occasional supervillain. Or sneaking past the ones that aren't bosses... but still. The characters in the main cast are boring, forgettable cliches. Their voice actors put forth as little effort as possible and the writers didn't try very hard with them, either. The secondary characters, though, are often very endearing and well-acted. James Hong makes a delightful cameo. Stephen Heck, Sie, Albatross, and too many more to mention are also greatly more entertaining characters than the main ones. It's fair to say that the more central a character is to the plot, the worse their writing and voice acting gets, with Mike Thorton (the main character) easily being the worst.The main plot isn't a strong point. It's about secret agents trying to stop an evil CEO from starting a world war. Fortunately, though, it frequently takes a back seat to the secondary plot arcs and doesn't get much more than (jarringly frequent) lipservice throughout most of the game. You'll have to put up with some characters bringing up the main plot every chance they get, but it's mercifully rare for gameplay to be impacted by it.The dialogue itself is of drastically varying quality (see above), but the user interface that directs your character's responses in conversation is an unmitigated disaster. If you've played Fallout 4 you know what to expect - you can push one of four buttons to make your character say something, but it's impossible to know what precisely you're making him say without prior knowledge. You get a vague indication of the tone and topic you're going to be responding with and a very limited time to peruse your options. And some characters will only like you if you mash the B button [(for example) (Xbox360 controller)], while others will hate you if you mash the B button, which is as dumb as it sounds.So who do I recommend this game to? If you thoroughly enjoyed Deus Ex 1, bought a copy of Deus Ex: Human Revolution, and it made you facepalm so hard that it sounded like a gun went off, you'll find Alpha Protocol a much needed relief. If you're looking for a believable spy thriller in an original setting, you'll probably find this game painful to play. If you're the type that played Fallout: New Vegas as an angry, drugged-up whackjob that goes around starting fights with everything that moves (or did so at least once and enjoyed it), and want something that brings that catharsis back now that you've played F:NV to death, you'll be amply able to scratch that itch in Alpha Protocol. If you prefer your stealth games to have high-tension, highly difficult stealth like Splinter Cell: Chaos Theory, Alpha Protocol will certainly dissapoint you. To me, it's incredibly fun in spite of most of its flaws, and partly because of its other flaws.

content:
Posted: March 3
												Yes, it has flaws but I can't help but love this game so far.Firstly, IT WORKS. No need for RadeonPro tweaking, no stuttering, no FPS drops, no noticeable glitches or bugs (so far). To be honest, I'd forgotten the difference it makes to have a game that just immediately functions as it should after download to my enjoyment of it. If every game worked this straightforwardly, I'd be a truly happy gamer.Secondly, it's just fun. Just fun. In terms of combat, not epically challenging, it seems (depending on what character build you use; stealth and hand-to-hand seem to hands down beat firearms in almost all situations).Thirdly, the dialogue system is really intriguing. Some other reviewers have criticised the vagueness of the dialogue choices, but it hasn't seemed that problematic to me. The voice acting is epic. I love the loadout customisation options too.BUT, use an Xbox controller to play it. The hacking minigame is frustrating WITH a controller, and basically impossible without. That minigame is my only gripe really. It seems to require 20-20 vision and has a timer that clearly has a dinner appointment after finishing work, its that fast.I bought the game on sale and it was totally worth it. If you don't have an Xbox controller, you'll have to factor in that cost to be able to enjoy it, to be honest. But as a game, it's fun, intriguing, pretty good looking and best of all...IT WORKS. :):):)
