content:
Posted: June 28, 2014
												This would have been a great espionage RPG, but unfortunately, it simply isn't anything good gameplay-wise.Pros:1. nice story premise so far since I haven't finished the game yet2. some very generic protrayals of characters but reasonably good voice acting3. the leveling system and skills are kinda fun4. in-game soundtracks are not dull and some are actually very intensely intriguing at timesCons:1. the extremely outdated graphics: obsidian made two RPG games in 2010, one is Fallout: New Vegas which looked like it was from 2006, another was called Alpha Protocol that looked like it was from 2004. Seriously, Splinter Cell Chaos Theory looks a lot better than this2. I've seen much cleverer enemy AI in mobile games3. as if the enemies annoying patterns of behavior didn't ruin the game's realism enough, tons of terrible game design choices managed to make it even worse for the players. seriously, does anybody know how to vault a FU-CK-ING waist-high obstacle in this game?4. speaking of game design choices, this is a mother-loving stealth game in nature! even players are given the choices to go into every frickin mission gun-blazing, a lot of us still want some honest-to-god satisfying stealth action! meaning not just to stick into any cover possible while encountering enemy patrols, and in many instances, thanks to the game's brilliant AI and level designs, you still get spotted while doing that, or won't get spotted even if you are virtually right in the middle of an enemy's line of sight, depending on your luck. And of course, thanks to the game's fu-gly lighting and shadow effects, definitely no light and darkness element included in this game's concept of stealth, right, maybe it wanted to be something like Metal Gear Solid 4 oh and by the way when I write this review MGS series already started introducing this element since the release of Ground Zero far as I know.5. at least this game managed to exceed what MGS was capable of doing in one aspect: the total clunkiness and awkwardness of all the aspects of combat system. Before playing this game I thought MGS series action and shooting and basically everything concerning its core stealth-action-based gameplay was a clunky mess (which thankfully seems to have been improved a LOT in MGSV), but after playing this game............................... I can only say that I basically impatiently rushed through every single part of the game that REQUIRES ME PLAYING just to see how the plot was going to develop, and this is probably the first time I actually want to stay longer in the cutscenes and conversation sequences in an Action Role Playing Game...No idea why so many users on steam would recommend this game, calling it 'gem of an RPG', this whole game was a bloody MESS of an RPG resulting from a series of awfully poor design choices and development executions, though the initial concept was very innovative and the actual story of this game is quite intriguing.My score for this game 6/10, NOT RECOMMENDED unless you really think you can stomach whatever nasty things this game shoves down your throat during your unenjoyable playthrough.P.s. Maybe Obsidian Entertainment should go back and develop more spin-offs or sequals for some already successful franchises instead of obtaining and working on their own IPs, it has been proven they're simply not cut out for this, at least not yet.

content:
Posted: April 22, 2016
												Alpha Protocol is a game that I really wanted to like. I tried to look past the flaws that this game had, but I honestly couldn't. The best thing I can say about Alpha Protocol is that it at least tried to be something different, but even if you try to do something different, it doesn't mean that it will always be good.Alpha Protocol has a unique concept, an espionage RPG. I was surprised to see that this sort of idea, hadn't been done that often in gaming and that is one thing that I respect this game for doing. The main problem with this however is that in my opinion, Alpha Protocol doesn't really use any of the unique ideas it brings to the table that well and the basic stuff that are required to make a good game (like gameplay, playability and graphics) aren't really focused on as they put most of their thought, time and care into trying to implement these ideas to try and live up to it's name "an espionage RPG."One of the biggest problems Alpha Protocol has is in it's gameplay. Nearly everything in the gameplay falls flat. While the training section at the beginning of the game, does show off some great ideas for an espionage RPG like sneaking mechanics, combat and gadgets, I didn't feel like I was having any fun playing this or doing any of these ideas for gameplay because in the end, that's what I was thinking they were, just some ideas. I felt like these ideas were only half executed. The ideas are there, but they just stopped after that. Sneaking is basically useless because the AI is really bad. Gun combat feels restricted an the sensitivity never feels right no matter what you set it to. Melee combat, while it's better than gun combat, feels slippery for the majority of the time, but at least it was more controllable than the gun Gadgets are basically useless in combat because you can't really tell where they'll land. There's no targeting ridicule for them so you just need to predict where they'll land.Graphics are for the most part good however there are several flaws with them. There is quite a lot of slow loading textures from time to time and the longer I played, the more frequently these occurred. There is also a bit of pop in going on quite a bit. Apart from that there isn't much to say about the graphics. They're decent but they could have gotten more polish before release like the rest of the game.The sound seemed to repeatedly cutting out randomly for some reason throughout my play time as well. However, this didn't affect my overall feeling towards the game in any way and I easily ignored it as it wasn't too big of a deal.In this review, it might come off like I hate Alpha Protocol and even though that's true, there's still some good ideas that are put into Alpha Protocol, which might have been good if they developed these ideas further. The stuff that is common to see and expect in an RPG is present in Alpha Protocol but these things we have seen done a bunch of times are exactly that. Alpha Protocol does nothing to change the styles that are common in RPGs except for the dialogue options, which is one of the best I've seen.Overall, Alpha Protocol is buggy and generic. It barely does anything to stand out from the crowd and when it tries to do this, it usually falls flat. However, it still uses some ideas which I hope to see in RPGs in a future and if the developers of this game were to make a sequel, maybe tweaking the game a bit, I would definitely buy the sequel to see if these ideas are developed more.Pros+ Some good ideas+ Great concept+ Good mechanics+ OK graphicsCons- Underdeveloped ideas- Terrible AI- Restricted/slippery combat- Slow loading texturesFinal verdict: 3/10Steam curator group: http://steamcommunity.com/groups/MellowReviews

content:
Posted: March 22, 2015
												I bought this game expecting a tense spy drama like Tinker Tailor Soldier Spy or The Americans. After spending 10 minutes preparing the perfect disguise for my initial mission, the arms dealer's henchmen immediately read me as American and opened fire. So much for spying. Well, perhaps i could at least sneak? Nope. Aside from the janky controls and flaky stealth mechanics, the game repeatedly forces you into frontal assaults anyway. The most appalling part, for me, is when it proudly sums up all your kills at the end of the mission, and awards you perks for them, which really drives home just how messed up the story is. Running around killing (or even "just" disabling) hundreds of foreign nationals without any rules of engagement made me feel a lot more like a terrorist than an operative.And it's a shame because there is some good dialog in there. The story is in the vein of Nikita, conspiracy on top of conspiracy, and it is fun to choose alliances and watch the drama unfold. Just fun enough for me to complete the game. But the boss battles, the waves of enemies, the woefully linear levels... At some points in the game you have to make life or death decisions, but i just didn't care because the majority of the game is built around you killing people with no consequence at all. If there had been more dialog, undercover missions, an open world to explore, any opportunity to downshift and become invested in the places i visited, then the poor decisions i made may have had some emotional resonance. Instead i was sent straight on to the next mission with more faceless bad guys and superhuman bosses to kill. Hard to recommend unless you are really craving a spy fix and are willing to put up with a lot of mindless shooting.

content:
Posted: June 21, 2014
												If you picked the Bug (right, bugs) the Airfield mission as your first mission out of three, you WILL think this game sucks:-Enemies sometimes can see you even though you are behind a cover. This happened to me twice in that mission. What's the point of encouraging stealth approach while the gunner can see you through the cover and pull the alarm?-The game has checkpoints while it also allows you to save/load at anytime during a mission. However when I reloaded the checkpoint in the Bug the Airfield mission, all the enemies in the area disappeared. This bug is helpful for me to explore the area, but it completely ruins the fun of the game. However those issues are not that severe in the later missions.Also, sometimes you can't climb ladders or get behind the cover unless you adjust your camera position or simply "try again". Such problems are quite devastating if you want to go for a stealth approach.Besides the technical issues, Alpha Protocol is full of dialogues and text if you like narrative elements in a game.I wouldn't recommend this game to a friend, because the bugs are ruining the gameplay experience. If you are curious about the game, feel free to pick it up.

content:
Posted: June 4, 2015
												I cannot believe I was stupid enough to impulse-buy this ♥♥♥♥ing game for fifteen ♥♥♥♥ing dollars. It is horribly, mind blowingly generic. The generic, boring blandness of this game is just outstanding. It washed over me like the tidal wave crashing down on Patrick Swayze at the end of Point Break. It is like a copy of Splinter Cell Conviction, if of course you took every single last tiny detail about that game that made it so great including sound, gameplay, and graphics, and flushed it all down the toilet, then you have this game. I was shaking my head at how bad it is the entire time I was playing it. A worthless ♥♥♥♥ing waste of anyones time. And I mean anyone. I hope anyone involved with making this game ♥♥♥♥ing dies.The stealth part of the game, if you can even call it that, just sucks nuts. The worst thing about this game is how horribly, mind bogglingly inaccurate all weapons are. I seriously wonder what the ♥♥♥♥ they were thinking when they did this. Pistols = luck. Assault rifles = horrible. And shotguns = I can be right in front of a guy not more than 4ft away, aiming directly into his upper torso with the shotgun, and where any other shotgun, game or real life, would blow a hole right through him, 95% of the pellets miss him. It's as bad if not worse than the shotgun in Doom 3. You might be able to increase accuracy with obtained mods and skills as the game progresses but it's too bad this game just generally sucks so bad and is such a overall ♥♥♥♥♥♥ poorly made game that you won't want to. One of the worst games I've ever played. The level design is horrible: incredibly linear and you go from one box shaped room or area to the next box shaped one while killing incompetant enemies with the most innaccurate weapons ever put in a game. The graphics are really bad and the levels all use the same God awful boring colors.You want a game like this that is actually fun? Play Binary Domain instead. Or any Splinter Cell game for that matter. You know what, thumb wrestling is more fun than this garbage.Yet another game that completely sucks in general terms but I get all downvotes because people think, for whatever ♥♥♥♥ed up reasoning, that it has any redeeming qualities, in which it actually has exactly zero. If you like this game I feel bad for how easily impressible you are and your taste in games must be incredibly bad. 3/10

content:
Posted: April 21
												This might seriously be one of the worst games I've ever played. The controls feel clunky as all mess using K/M and the game itself is just riddled with bugs. I played this for two days, no problem. I start it up today and it will run the launcher, but not actually start the game. I tried like four times! The gamepaly itself is pretty awful, as the stealth mechanics are just broken beyond my comprehension. If a guard is staring right at you without any cover, you will remain unspotted. But hide behind some boxes with tons of cover and crouched, across a room? Guaranteed alarm going off. The other thing that frustrates me about this game is that it forces you to either listen to the entirety of spoken cutscenes or skip everything completely. I can read faster than they talk, why not just let me advance the dialog line-by-line like most other modern RPGs of this type? The graphics are passable, but sometimes it seems like they glitch out. Watching Mike's face during a lot of conversations, his grin overextends to like his ear and it's almost as cringeworthy to behold as the ME: Andromeda facial animations. Final thoughts: I've tried to like this game for a long time and every time I pick it up, it's just not fun and feels dreadful to play. I think I got it on sale for like $1.50, so not a lot of money lost, but still too much for such a turd. Deleting from my collection.

												I have to recommend Alpha Protocol purely on the unqiueness of premise: no other game (that I know of) so effectely attempts to combine stealth and RPG gameplay. I've never enountered anything so close to D&D + 007. At the same time, Alpha Protocol is buggy, poorly-written, and suffers from lackluster combat. content:
Posted: February 22, 2015
												That gunplay is some of the worst I have seen in a game to date. It controls worse than The Last of Us (origonal) Its so frustrating to be spoted so easily and have to resort to using such a crap gunplay system. The mechanic where you have to hold the cursor over the target for 4 or 5 seconds to get a shot on them is downright ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥.The dialouge is so dry and boring that I found myself daydreaming while I was talking to someone. It also suffers from the, "Lets give the player dialouge options but force them to pick in 3 seconds and only give them a vauge one word descriptor of what the player character is going to respond with." virus. Theres a reputation system with each character and you are told that it doesnt matter if they end up liking or hating you as you get different outcomes and "there isnt a right way." This pisses me off however, because you have no idea what the outcomes will be so you might as well just let the dialouge try auto finish. One could argue that you are supposed to roleplay but I would respond with, "How?" How the ♥♥♥♥ am i supposed to roleplay when the options for most dialouge trees are "Professional", "Suave", or "Angry?" The game very much feels like a lazy console port. You have to individually equip skills to use them (instead of using the 100 keys on my keyboard) and the menus are frustratingly designed.The computer hacking with mouse and keyboard is ♥♥♥♥ing horrible and I cant figure out how this game was released like that. You have a computer screen full of a word search grid where all the letters are changing. You have 2 codes on the right and left that you have to find in the word search and match up. You controll the left code with wasd and space to confirm and the right with the mouse (moveing left with the mouse will move it left ect.) and left clicking to confirm. I wanted to shoot myself in the♥♥♥♥♥♥trying to use this system.To top it off, I died in the first mission and clicked to reload my last checkpoint and the game crashed. -.-Im told this laid the groundwork for games like mass effect and i just cant see how. I doubt I will be revisiting this game in the future as I have roughly 200 more games untouched in my library and a few of them have to be good.

												This game blends RPG with Action/Stealth elements, and is at its best on the RPG side of things. THe action/stealth parts, unfortunately, are too unpolished and really subpar. From poor AI to guns that are laughably imprecise, stealth that doesn't quite work (many portions force you out of stealth and into combar so stealth is not that useful in the end). This game would have been a lot more enjoyable just sticking with the RPG parts, which Obsidian is good at - or otherwise spend a lot more time polishing the actiony part of the game. There are a lot of good ideas in this game, but in the end I can't quite recommend this game

content:
Posted: March 16, 2014
												The game has a very interesting premise, but fails its potential utterly. The gameplay fells clunky, unpolished and generally boring. The interface is not particularly good either. Oh, let's not forget the much praised dialog system. The dialogs themselves are not bad, characters are interesting and the story looks engaging. But the gameplaywise the system is a mess. Firstly, it's even worse than in Mass Effect, not giving you a slightest idea what your character is going to say. Secondly, the awful timer that does not allow to choose your dialog option carefully and thoughtfully. You see, The Walking Dead gave the example how a time limit in choosing a dialog response could be done properly. There you had plenty of time to choose your response for the most part. And in those cases where you had a very short time limit to choose it was done to give a feeling of intensity of a situation. Here, in Alpha Protocol, you always have a very tight time limit regardless of situation, which does not provide for player anything but constant irritation.

number of helpful: 11 of 25 people (44%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 21, 2013
												In almost every aspect attributable to a videogame, Alpha Protocol fails to impress. The graphics are ugly, the artstyle is generic, the gunplay is tripe and the AI borderline schizophrenic.It is a testament, then, to Obisdian's writing staff that this game is merely mediocre.The game has a solid RPG heritage and this shows, with the RPG elements arguably being the game's only true strength. There are some solid choice and consequences here and the leveling system is basic, but functional (operating on a hybrid of perks and number-based attribute upgrades). The story the game weaves between flashbacks is not in itself ground-breaking nor is it free from a number of tried and tested spy clichés, but the influence the game allows you to have on the story is commendable. There's no TW2-tier decision here, but characters will reflect on how you played a level and this will result in other characters reacting accordingly. For example, playing steathily throughout will mean characters that respect stealthy-operators are more likely to respect you and your methods, perhaps resulting in an allegiance several levels later. These are relatively minor touches, but they permeate the game's writing, with the game itself having a number of different endings depending on who you allied with and how friendly you were with them.The gunplay is heavily influenced by the RPG mechanics of old, with the reticule taking some time to focus on weapons you are not trained for. However, even when your character is maxed out on a weapon's skill, the gunplay fails to feel anything better than floaty and ill-equipped. I ended up playing as a sneaky spy in an effort to avoid the gunplay.Stealth in this game is hampered by the AI. It's laughably stupid in some cases and borderline psychic in others. The game gets around this in later levels by allowing your character to become invisible (with no in-game reasoning as to why) but this quickly becomes over-powered as your pour more points into stealth.To be sure, I found Alpha Protocol a deeply unsatisfying experience, but I found myself constantly wanting to like it as I progressed, there's a distinct lack of good RPGs set in the spy mythos. This is a game that was clearly crafted with a small budget and unlike other budget games (such as DMC1) which inspire a certain cheap charm to them, you can't help but lament the lost potential with Alpha Protocol.

number of helpful: 8 of 19 people (42%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 22, 2016
												Take a game with a great dialog system, an interesting story, and no morality system but rather meaningful choices and what do you get?A game I can't recommend.   I'm a little shocked at this game, because on the surface it's everything I should want.  The game has a very innovative gameplay system, where conversations matter, and the game doesn't rely on a basic morality, but rather what you say and what you do. On paper, this is an incredible game, and honestly I'd love to love it I just can't.   The problem with this game is essentially, I've tried to play it three times, and I've failed to get involved.  The first time I didn't give the game a real try, so we can forget about that. The second one I played three levels, and I started the game as a "Recruit" putting my points into weapons skill to try to make weapons better.  It didn't so I gave up.  About a week after that I heard if you put the points into stealth the game becomes incredibly easy.  I tried that, and ran into a third problem. The first thing to say is this game's dialog choices are incredible.  It reminds me of Catherine a little in that EVERY thing you do feels important and matters.  The difference from Catherine is instead of a morality system, there's just important dialogs everywhere.The downside of this for the third playthrough is none of these dialogs are that different or skippable.  And there are some long dialogs in this game, and while there's a decision how the player will respond, most of the time, it only gives a "relationship" point and continues the same dry dialog with minimal acknowledgement.   Did I want to sit through 4 hours of hearing the same dialog a second time with no way to skip?  I chose no.  But it wasn't only that. The other major problem with this game is the combat.  Dear god, that combat is SO bad.   I realize Obsidian was trying to make the combat weaker so stealth became a viable option but often I feel the player can't even aim a gun and can only get a solid firing reticule by standing around for solid minutes.  It's BAD.   Watch a video and you can see why. I don't understand this design decision because it takes what is actually a really good game, down to the bad game territory.  There's a number of games that have figured this out.  Metal Gear Solid 5 heavily pushes stealth but when you make a mistake you can go in guns blazing and save your life most of the time, or hide again.  But a SINGLE mistake here, and you're either going guns blazing for the rest of the level (poorly) or you're reloading from the last checkpoint which is usually far away. I can't really complain about the combat enough, because it's one of the core gameplay in the game, and it really ruined my love for the game. There's one final issue that people have with this game and I agree with it.  The game is NOT made for PC.  It's a port and I'll accept that most of the time.  I get it.   However in this game, there's three mini games.  A game where you clip and trace paths works great.  A game where you lock pick is quite annoying but still can mostly work, especially if you have a gamepad.     But the game where you hack just seems almost unplayable on the computer, maybe it's always that bad but it's annoying as hell. I gave this game a solid try, three solid tries in my opinion.  And I could never get far.  It's not the worst game in the world, but there's no way I can recommend it as the combat is just painful.Here's the final thought.  Maybe in the future I'll try this game again and get through the entire game and love it.  That's possible, but I won't change my recommendation because NO game should take four attempts to get into.  No game should make loving it this hard.   I might turn around and say "I love you" to the game one day soon but that will be an abusive love.  And that's not ok!

content:
Posted: November 28, 2013
												This is one of the worst games I've ever played, and I have played Superman 64.This game has as many horrendous bugs as Australia in the Summer, it's pretty much broken. Sometimes your checkpoints will vanish, or you won't be able to start a level, or your saves will disappear, and stuff like that.If you were looking for anything like a game about being a spy, sneaking around killing in the night, this really is not it. You can pretty much spend your skill points on speed and martial arts, run towards armed enemies and just kick them in the face until they die, no sneaking required.Actually, you find it extremely difficult to do anything except running towards enemies and kick them on the face because it's so ill designed. Being a "spy" in these levels require neither cover, silence or strategy but just plain luck. Enemies will just randomly discover you, shot you, kill you, and then the level won't restart anymore because of some random bug.Don't buy this.

number of helpful: 2 of 7 people (29%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 21, 2014
												In the hour that I've played this game, I wasn't appealed by it. Alpha Protocol boxes with the greater spy-espionage games by entering itself into the genre with its elements. The potential is there, but I couldn't recommend it because of the fact the gameplay itself is unrefined. The graphics are beautiful, as well as the controls. The story line is your typical run-of-the-mill type which everybody can basically predict. There will be a lot of places where you get stuck if you don't memorize basically the whole layout of the game, which will easily aggrivate even the most seasoned of espionage veterans to a hightened extent. Your movements and timing have to be very intricate, as if you're playing a deep game of chess. Having to reload your checkpoints and redo whole sections of the game over and over again because you missed one tiny detail gets menotonous and dull very quickly.As I previously stated, the game has serious potential, but in my eyes, it's unfinished at best. If you're a hardcore espionage veteran, then I could recommend this game to you. If not, then I'd stay on the tracks of Syphon Filter or games such as. I wouldn't recommend this game for casual players at all.

Posted: February 22, 2011
												This was...okay. I'm not sure what happened with this game. The recommended game requirements suggested my computer had what it took to run this with no problem but I jump in and it's choppy, the aiming took hours to adapt to the way the crosshairs jumped around, it's buggy as all hell and at times the dialog could be downright corny as the worse B-movie you've ever seen; plus it is truly the type of game you need a strategy guide open at all times if you want things to go the way you want them to. But it was different, the story was at least half-way interesting and the narrative can change depending on your choices throughout the game. There's a lot to complain about but if there was a part two in the future I would consider it depending on what the reviews say about what has been improved. In summary, buyer beware.

number of helpful: 2 of 7 people (29%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 30, 2013
												The best way I can describe Alpha Protocol is for me, to describe what it feels like. It's a concerted and deliberate knockoff of another game. It has very flat and often outrageously immature and ridiculous dialogue. THe gameplay feels like someone really badly wanted an espionage game that played like Bioshock and Half-Life 2. The premise is thin and barely even attempted, let alone executed. Alpha Protocol in summary is one company's attempt to make a knockoff of Deus Ex - which is in many ways a vastly superior game, and on far more than just the grounds of technological development. I found this game crass, needlessly overthought in many cases, and skin-peelingly bad for characters and character development.

content:
Posted: April 4, 2014
												Good, Awesome, Perfect...? NO! It's a crappy "RPG" game or they just tell you that, but rly wtf?!-Only RPG element i saw in the game was that you can level up, use "AP" which you get by leveling up and then you can buy skills which aren't bad, but they won't help you through the game. You don't need them at all.-Graphics aren't too bad, but there were some graphic busd, like you could see through a wall, or the light of the other room gets trough the wall, and stuff like that.-AI is crappy, once there was a firefight, and an enemy guy was just standing next to me like: -Hey there What'ya Doin'?-There were some good ideas, but why the hell did they made such a bad aiming system?! Even if you target the guy and get a "RED CRITICAL CROSS THINGY" mostly you can't hit them, and if the enemy comes like: -"SURPRISE MODAFAKA" You don1t have a chance to fight back, because if you don't aim, then you won't hit anything, and to shoot the target, you need to fire like 100 bullets with aiming, OR you can wait like 5-10 seconds to target the enemy, and get that "RED CRITICAL CROSS THINGY", but you can't because you're dead!-Story is...  BULLSH*T! !!!!SPOILER!!!!  First mission you need to "get out" of a base, first you won't get out, Second you kill like a lot of people, and then they say this was normal come you work for us... And F*CK Those guys you killed i don't give a damn...-Friend system? RLY?  If you interact with people you can choose what to say. And even if you say something like F*CK YOU! , they will only be angry with you, but i don't see why this would be bad for me...-QUICK TIME EVENTS!  The only good thing... is when you don't need to do theese. Theese quick time events are hard, and if you miss something, then you loose time and if you fail then you do them again. Theres hacking, lockpicking, and alarm disarming. Lockpicking is easy, alarm disarming isn't too bad, BUT HACKING IS LIKE HELL!So if you want to buy this game, buy it, and then KILL YOURSELF!

content:
Posted: May 12, 2015
												I have never found a game I was sick of within such a short time. And the sad thing is, it looked great. Realistic stealth takedowns and being able to choose your response type, building or ruining relationships and having positive or negative consequences for either and customization. This game looked like gold. And people said it was gold minus a few bugs.But that's just it. I went into mission one ready for a great experience and I'm already being seen from literally across the map and alarms are raised without any trace of me doing anything. I wouldn't mind messing up and being seen, but humans don't have x-ray vision. Another problem is your character has to stand up every single time he switches cover, so it makes the mechanic completely useless and what with AI being able to be God already without being near them, you will be seen. This game was released in 2010. It's been 5 years and still these bugs are there? Alright Sega. There's my hard earned 3 dollars for you. I didn't expect to see current or next gen games from Sega this broken. That really disappoints. If the bugs were fixed it'd be perfect. But Sega clearly didn't care about this title. So please save your money on this one.

number of helpful: 0 of 3 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 18, 2015
												If the game isn't worth 50% of its price, I won't recommend it at all, and that is the case here.Good:+ Timed dialogue keeps you involved in the story+ The missions are decently varied+ You can go either full lethal or full nonlethal+ Decent variation in character builds+ Decent variation in roleplaying options in dialogueBad:- Levels balanced horribly: some builds completely unviable for certain levels- Checkpoint system with no manual save for no other reason than Halo and consolitis- Checkpoints are way too far apart: hope you can do everything right the first time- Dialogue horribly cheesy- Story utterly banal, Clancyesque, perhaps on the level of Army of Two, about PMCs and the military-industrial complex- Numerous bugs: often after reloading a checkpoint because you died from poor level design, enemies and the opportunity to collect their XP will vanish- Not open world and hardly even a hub; the safehouses just exist as extended inventory screens- Attempts Deus Ex-style gameplay variation but without the numerous routes and proper scaling you would expect- Graphics about as awful as you could expect of Unreal Engine 3- Reputation gain/loss dialogue options sometimes are unpredictable, even after reading dossiers- Weapons absurdly inaccurate for a supposedly trained agent (hearkens back to DX where you basically have to master firearms skills to be using them)- Quite short: even if it were padded out with open world retreading it would still be less than 15 hours long- Ridiculously strong, "GTA" bosses with giant health pools that you have to pour hundreds of rounds into, including an emo teen girl- Keyboard + mouse controls completely terrible: hacking next to impossible in this setup (consider gamepad required)- For a game about espionage, stealth is totally naff with enemies that can see in the dark across unlit fields, few avoidance routes and mechanics that are between Zelda 64 and Metal Gear Solid chronologically (1998 or so; of course less detailed than Thief 1)- For a game where stealth is terrible, the shooting mechanics are not very good either. Cover is slightly more useful than in Mass Effect 1, but mainly because you are much more killable. Magnetic cover is sloppy and will leave you exposed, solution: better master a firearm skill, especially for the boss fights which frequently take place in arenas- As is often paraphrased from TS Eliot, "Good writers borrow, great writers steal." In this game, the designers borrow rather than steal; the same can be said for the programmers and writers. The game is obviously "heavily inspired" by Mass Effect (skill tree configuration, combat style, dialogue wheel, even specific skills) and Army of Two (mission selection, lack of hub, ragdoll-style slapstick combat, comical enemies, PMC-based military-industrial-complex story). These games are the only reason this one exists at all. The engine is licensed and the game progression is sterile and controlled and yet still has bugs. This is par for the course for Obsidian, though: they have made their careers out of making sequels and derivative IPs of "discount" quality.I got the game for $2.99. I would rate it at about $5. Until that's its price, I can't recommend it.

number of helpful: 2 of 8 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 20, 2014
												I recently finished this game.I think the game really is not as good as it is being said here. I don't see the whole "first espionage RPG" slogan either because it is really just a low budget deus ex (I have played first and second one through).The story is not special: At the end it goes down to save the world cliche. Not gonna spoil anything so you should try yourself and see. I failed to see any interesting twists though, everything was pretty much obvious from get go as the game plays "in the past".The production value is rather low. Aside from the things like weak graphics and controls, there are some very annoying stuff too. For example: If you take the "wrong" door out of two options, you might advance and the door you took just permanently closes behind you, giving you no chance to explore/finish side objectives.I really would not bother. In this time and age there are so many good, affordable options out there that deserve to be seen more than alpha protocol. By no means is the game "terrible" but at the end it will leave a bad taste in my opinion over the time spent.

content:
Posted: March 5
												I'm usually a giant fan of Obsidian games, but I just can't play another second of this one.I understand that the game is from 2010, but this is just bad.  Controlling with keyboard and mouse is pretty splotchy at best, and just clunky as hell to try and move your guy around.  But I lost all interest in the hacking portion of the game.10 minutes.  10 minutes I spent working on trying to figure out what the hell was going on with the hacking, and when I finally figured it out, it took another 7 tries to hack the first computer.  Given the nature of the game I figured that this was going to come up later and this is where I stopped.  Hacking, ironically enough, broke this game for me.  I will not play another moment of this game due to the fact that I will probably miss something important later, or get to the point where hacking is dire to continue and I summon an entire battalion to wipe me out due to my inept ability to hack a computer within 6 seconds.  Nope, sorry Obsidian, I'm rating you a negative for the first time ever.

number of helpful: 6 of 17 people (35%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 1, 2014
Alpha Protocol fails to impress on any level.Pros:  Sound, StoryCons:  Graphics, Control, Gameplay, BugsFrom the voice acting to the ambient sounds, Alpha Protocol, even in name, sounds good.  The story follows a more realistic route than most other games in the genre, which can be refreshing.However, Alpha Protocol's graphics and animations appear dull and wooden, trailing behind even its 2010 peers.  Control is poor with both the controller and keyboard/mouse, though this is partly because of the biggest flaw: gameplay.  The gameplay is absolutely atrocious in every aspect.  The minigames irritate at first but later become so frustrating that bypass gadgets are a godsend.  The gunplay is poor; our 'elite' agent takes seconds to hit a still, unaware target.  The choices are misrepresented: 'suave' can be cheeky or it can be arrogant jerk, whatever the developer decided at the time.Overall, Alpha Protocol is a mediocre port of a mediocre game.6/10

content:

												The game has a nice potential and reminds a bit Deus Ex Human Revolution (just a bit), but weird controls and lack of quicksave make it a torture to play. And where is pleasure in that.I gave up pretty early, when I had to hack into a terminal by moving two passwords around an array of changing characters - one password is moved with keyboard keys, the other with mouse (!) and then you're supposed to press mouse keys to fix it, but it doesn't fix. It triggered an alarm, and I was brought back to the place with 3 guards that I have to go through again. When there is a hint on the screen, like "press Z to [...] and X to [...]" - you can't exit to menu. Escape just doesn't bring the menu, or exit a menu... I just don't understand sometimes, how can a company spend millions on making a game, and not spend 2 hours to check things like that and see how bad it is.

content:
Posted: October 17, 2016
												Alpha Protocol made me think – what does a shoddy game have to do to get a free pass despite all of its flaws? Even the worst of the bunch sometimes have redeemable qualities, right?Well, Alpha Protocol definitely has a cool premise going for it. It's inspired by futuristic superspy flicks, and if only it had slightly more personality and charm, I might say it's worth overlooking boring gameplay, throwaway RPG mechanics, linear level design and other issues that plague the game. But Alpha Protocol has no charm. Everything about it is plain, bland, lifeless and uninteresting. The writing is only "okay". The story is merely "passable". Same with voice acting. It's the definition of mediocrity, like a James Bond movie reenacted in a school theatre play (come to think of it, that might actually be a fun thing to watch).I've played quite a few bad games that were enjoyable regardless, as I'm sure many people have. Deadly Premonition, for example, got away with terrible design largely because of its wild story and superb atmosphere. Games like Oblivion got away with questionable gameplay mechanics because of their deep and intricate world building. This game has none of those qualities. It starts with a promising setup and never does anything meaningful with it. As you can see, I've only played it for 5 hours. Despite the fact that it's not even a double digit, I still consider it a long time and would happily get those hours back if it was possible. But it's not. So don't repeat my mistake. Play the old Deus Ex instead. Or Splinter Cell. Anything, but not this.Oh, and whoever designed that hacking minigame deserves to have a stroboscope taped to their eyes.

content:
Posted: August 17, 2016
												No, no, no, no, no. This game is so badly designed, where do I even begin. By far the worst feature is a sort of "soft difficulty level" that they impose that seems to be based solely on your level. The effect of this is that you can never actually get good at any of the puzzles in the game - because as you invest in your character, the puzzles get harder at a much faster rate. Particularly if you are playing the game with a gamepad (which this style of game is well suited to, normally), at level 14 or so you will simply not physically be able to solve some of the puzzles in time.This wouldn't be a deal-breaker by itself, but combined with how much of the game's content (in the form of intel) is behind these puzzles, and how many of them in a row you have to pass before your next checkpoint, the game eventually becomes a nightmare for anyone who actually wants to experience the content.Also, there is way too much mandatory combat for a game that let's you invest almost exclusively in stealth.Also, the writing is like a male adolescent sex fantasy.There are some interesting bits - the intel system and the dialog system have potential, but they are utterly wasted in a game that becomes unplayable the more you play it in a certain play style.

												Well to be honest there isnt anything special here. The graphics, story, mechanics & every other aspect besides the skill tree is barely at moderate standards. A big point about this game is suppose to be the RPG element. Which with most games that means you have a decent amount of decisions to determine what type of roll you want to play. For example: stealthy or all out assualt mode. However this game forces you to either pick a door, safe or lock every other minute or 2, forcing a more stealthy character dynamic then I would prefer. And if you dont take the time to pick, crack or unlock. You literally can't finish the game. And its the same puzzles just over and over again. Not sure how this game has received so many positive reviews. I would recommend spending your money on a game thats more unique and less cookie cutter.

												Dialogues activly influence gameplay (eg will you fight with support or additional enemies), nice agent story in rogue James Bond style, give it a try!

Posted: January 2, 2016
												There is a lot of RPG out there but this one is quite different.Right now it is the only one Espionage RPG in the world.Critics from all over the world weren't impressed by this game and gave it mixed rating.But I really enjoyed this game. The whole concept of several secret agencies and how they fight with each other is unique and, more importantly, very interesting.The game has several distinct traits which differ her from other RPG:1.	During the game you will have a chance to meet many different people who can become your curator. Curators in this game do not participate in the missions but they help you providing information and bonuses. The better your relationship with your curator the larger bonuses you get. You can affect your relationships with curators during the missions.2.	Before a mission you have a chance to buy some useful information about the mission or even affect it somehow (for example, you can hire a person to drop a sniper rifle on the roof or poison a boss, which will make him weaker)3.	The conversations in the game often time-limited. The game doesn’t give your time to think carefully about your answers because, you know, when you are being interrogated you don’t have a chance to think about possible outcomes of your answer.The game has some flaws but I loved it, I loved the setting, the RPG system, the characters and the story.I recommend it to anyone who likes RPG.

Posted: April 2, 2014
												Alpha Protocol is a fairly decent game.  It has a lot of promise as an action-espionage game that combines stealth gameplay with social intrigue and roleplaying.  While it falls short, the target it was aiming for was a fairly high one, which puts the game at above average in my book.  It stumbled in its efforts, but it picked a rich, difficult goal, and it made a pretty good try.Positives:  Your decisions impact your gameplay and the story, the setting and factions are varied and interesting, and the interaction with the various characters is fairly well thought out.Negatives:  The game is pretty buggy, the save system is a course checkpoint system, and the action element is really lackluster.I would give this game a rough B grade.  It could definitely have been better, but I felt my time was well spent, and I will probably come back to this game in the future.  I spent roughly 25 hours on the game, and other than some frustrating mission conditionss and setup issues, I had a lot of fun.  I would recommend this game to people looking to invest their time in the setting and story, but not to those looking for to blow up some bad guys.BUG NOTE:  If you do try this game, make sure to keep action bound to spacebar for hacking in addition to your general preference.  You'll pretty much have to use the spacebar to lock in the keyboard side of a hack.

Posted: February 4, 2012
												"This is the best spy movie I have ever played."The world is incredibly fluid, and changes and reacts to your choice in a way no other game I've ever played has. The shooting is definitely clunky, but It's much more of an RPG than a third-person shooter, regardless of how it looks. The conversations have a timer for you to pick a response, which sounds like a complaint; It's not. This gives all dialog a very organic feel, much more like a real conversation. The reaction to your dialog is also very realistic, with characters even reacting if, say, you choose a suave dialog option followed by an aggressive one. They note the mood whiplash. Pretty much everything flows together and NPCs even seem to remember how you acted in your previous conversations.The missions themselves are very well done, and although the combat is sometimes hampered by clunky controls, they are very open, with many different approaches and solutions to most things, complimenting multiple playthroughs well.

Posted: July 15, 2011
												It's funny, if you go out on the web and type this game's name you'll get alot of reviews stating how bad it is. From the wonky gameplay mechanics to the poor A.I., Alpha Protocol had an image of a rushed game. Though these problems do arise there is one thing that I have to admit, this game possessed some of the best interactive dialogs I have ever played.Truth be told I had alot of fun with this one. Yes, this is no shooter. The controls are slow and melee combat is awkward, but even with these faults I found my self becoming a slave to this game. The dialog and story, though cookie cutter in the 'spy genre', were amazing! Posted: December 13, 2011
												Probably one of the finest spy games I've ever had the joy of playing, yes it's rough round the edges and parts of it feel rushed but it's the only game that has made me actually influence the course of the game and actually made me feel like a spy. You play as Mike Thornton, a rookie with a background of your choice, and that choice carries out throughout the game. The speech system is the finest ever in an rpg because it makes you think quick, and you will have to live with the consequences. Everything can lead onto something else and this makes for extreme replayability. The graphics in the game do look dated and there are some glitches/bugs lurking in the game, however I feel that the fun I had playing it vastly outweighed the cons and made me press on forward to see where Mike Thornton and I got to in the world of spying. 												This game is considerably underrated considering the lack of press coverage it received. While it's probably been compared to Deus Ex: Human Revolution far too much, it's an apt comparison - it's not quite at the same production value as Deus Ex, but if you enjoy Deus Ex, chances are pretty good you'll enjoy this. The stealth works reasonably well, and the game is much more forgiving if you do choose to shoot everyone in sight. Your time in Alpha Protocol is spent almost entirely on taking out enemies and navigating the level, with little to no data collection required. 												Forget what the reviews say. Sure, it's an Obsidian game, so there are bound to be a few bugs. But: it's an Obsidian game, and that means it's excellently written, and tons of fun to play. It really deserves a sequel, even though it's an excellent game in its own right (and no, there's no cliffhanger ending; it's wrapped up at the end). Think of it this way: it combines the brilliant writing/dialogue of Planescape, with the gameplay of Deus Ex, in third person. For the most part, it pulls this off brilliantly. Keep in mind that one playthrough of this game is going to be different from the next: how you interact with people determines how the story plays out, and will open up various different missions and plots, so multiple playthroughs are definitely worth it. After reading the reviews, I went into this game a bit skeptical, but I've become a convert. Buy this game!!

Posted: April 22, 2014
												I don’t get all the hatred that’s been directed at this game. I picked it up for $2 during a sale, and some professional game reviewers were warning to not even buy it at that price. Naturally, I had to see what all the fuss was about and…well…Alpha Protocol is really not a bad game.Not terribly original (a cross between Splinter Cell & Mass Effect in the CIA) and the story isn’t particularly memorable but the gameplay is solid & enjoyable. It’s not the best thing I’ve ever played but it is most certainly not the worst, either. That is, it’s strange to me when professional media praises total garbage like Dragon Age 2 yet trashes Alpha Protocol.I’ve seen other reviewers complain about the AI in Alpha Protocol and various other glitches. Never had any problem with either of those things. Graphics were nice, music and voice acting were both acceptable. The story is nothing groundbreaking and a bit predictable given the way espionage stories go these days (America is the REAL enemy! Dun dun dunnn!) but it’s still fun to engage in the different relationships and choices you can make which have a real impact on the plot. And the gameplay is the glue that holds everything together; not revolutionary but good enough. The only drawback to Alpha Protocol is that it’s rather forgettable and you won’t have any reason to replay it unless you want to witness some of the multiple story paths. You can expect to spend somewhere around 20 hours and will have a good time during that, though. It’s a shame that this first entry got savaged because it really could have turned into a good series. Instead we have Assassin’s Creed Part 8 and Final Fantasy 13 Part 3. Oh well.

Posted: July 16, 2014
												Alpha Protocol can be frustrating as hell at times but it’s well worth a play through. The story is very reactive to the player’s choices as far as I can tell, with your alliances and the outcomes of your missions drastically altering how the story plays out. Your actions outside of dialogues carry weight too; even how you deal with enemies can lead to different outcomes.The combat is decent. It’s a little clunky and could have done with a bit more polish, but it does get the job done. And I have to admit there’s a certain level of satisfaction when you manage to stealth your way through an area by using the Chain Shot ability. Speaking of the abilities, there isn’t much variety in them. I think the game could have done with some more skills to use.The character customization also isn't very good. You're stuck with a specific character and can barely alter his appearance, only being able to change his hair, beard, skin tone, eye color, glasses, and hat, all of which only have a few options. I think more customization of Thorton would have been good. All in all, it’s worth a look. Just don’t pay more than $10 for it, don’t expect some AAA Mass Effect quality, and keep in mind it's a stealth/action game first and an RPG second.

Posted: July 4, 2014
												Alpha Protocol was a surprisinly good game.When I started, I was expexting another poor Splinter Cell clone. But in the end I learned, that they can't be compared.Yes, you can sneak through like Sam Fisher, but you can also take different approaches. Want to roll heavily armored with big guns?No problem.Want to sabotage enemy turrets to shoot theirs owners? Go ahead.Many games promise to give you the freedom on how to play through, but this one really delivers it's promises.You have a fairly large skill tree, to customize your character, with stealth, different weapons (each weapon with its own skill tree)cmartial arts, technical aptitude, sabotage and toughness.So ewveryone should find something to their likes.With that as a base, you can follow different paths in each mission, you can even choose in which order to play through the missions, as they are started from you hideout and you have to decide where to go next.Throughout the game, but mostly in said hideout, you will watch conversations between the protagonist and different characters.For those conversations, you have to choose from for three to four answers to give.This is one of the few games where your choices actually matter.And I don't only talk about "Spare that guy's life, and he will appear later", each character you talk to, builds up a relationship with you.Either positive or negative. Everyone has their own personality and reacts different to your given answers.That said, your answers to choose from are always either charming, aggressive, or professional. Depending on the class you picked at the beginning (Soldier, Field Agent, Tech Specialist, Freelancer, Recruit or Veteran) you have a fourth choice.That will be for recruits and veterans. Those two don't have any preset talents and have to start from scratch.Another great thing are the well made boss fights, which are hard and unique.I mean, a boss who consumes cocaine during the fight, to boost his abilities and burst through the room?Disco lights to blind us, and Autograph's song "Turn Up The Radio" in the background through out the whole fight?Awsome!Probably one of the best boss fights ever made.After all the hype, a few words on the games down sides.Every single character anmiation looks ridiculous. Their movement reminded me of Toy Story's tin soldiers. Especially the sneak animation is really, really strange. It's a wonder that no one can hear the protagonist.The second bad thing is a common problem with most video games. The bad voice over.Though, not immersion breaking, you will have to watch bad lip synch here and there.To summarize the game in short: Intense, variety and freedom.I'll give this 7 out of 10 points.Really one you should try.

Posted: July 15, 2014
												Alpha Protocol is an enjoyable game but not without its flaws. The game is made by Obsidian and it would probably be fair to call it a sort of "James Bond Mass Effect." An interesting thing about the game is the way dialogue plays out. Unlike most RPGs that have a system where you can choose your own dialogue, you don't have an unlimited amount of time to pick your responses. You must choose to be one of the three "JB" prototypes the designers based the main character off of - Suave, like James Bond, Professional, like Jason Bourne, or Aggressive like Jack Bauer. Your choices feel like they impact the story more than similar choices in other games, though there are (I think) only three endings.As for actually carrying out your missions, the game plays like a third person shooter. Ultimately, there is little point in investing in skills outside of stealth and pistols for your first play through, as those are the over powered skills in the game. In fact, some bosses you might find near impossible without the pistol's special skill. Even with stealth skills, you might find it difficult to perfectly stealth certain missions. Running and gunning isn't really a very viable option on a first playthrough because most of the weapons require you to focus your aim on a target to get a critical hit (it kind of reminds me of the first Deus Ex, where you stay stationary with your reticle over a target until your shot lines up perfectly). There are a couple different minigames for hacking, lock picking, and disabling alarms and the like. The only one that kinda gave me problems was the hacking mini game, back when I first tried this game on the XBox 360. The way it works is, you have two sequences of alpha numeric characters that must be lined up on a screen of constantly changing alpha numerics (it kinda looks like the "code" in the Matrix movies, if that makes any sense). The bit you're trying to match will be static, so it's kind of a test of your eyesight and almost like a "Where's Waldo" thing. If you don't do it fast enough, the static bit of code will randomly change to another location, and then if you completely run down the timer you set off an alarm. It's been a LITTLE while since I played the game but I believe if you abort the hack before the timer runs down you can get another attempt or two depending on your skill and the difficulty of the hack.The game is fairly nonlinear, even from the start. You have the option of completing the tutorial missions for bonus XP, perks, etc or going straight into the missions. In the first locale you are given the choice of what missions to tackle when, and you can complete the "main" mission before finishing up all the side missions. Once the game branches out after the first mission, you can globe trot and handle the missions in any order you please, which can impact your relations with characters and change the parameters for other missions and unlock certain boss fights and so on. You definitely won't see all there is to see in the game in a single play through. If you beat the game on "Recruit" difficulty you unlock "Veteran" mode which gives you a whole slew of skill points at the start to play around with. It's not quite a New Game + but fairly similar.Alpha Protocol seems to be a love it or hate it kind of a game. If you can get past the gameplay quirks it's very enjoyable, and I'd definitely recommend picking it up. It seems to go on sale often so throw it on your wishlist and snag it at a good price!Final Score = 7.5/10

Posted: April 18, 2014
												This was a real buried gem of a game. I grabbed it during a sale for less than $5 on the thin promise of "Mass Effect with Super-Spies," and that turned out to be more or less exactly what was delivered. For all the negative press this game received, I found few flaws worth spiting the game for, and after two playthroughs I'm only disappointed I didn't find Alpha Protocol earlier.AP is a great find for people who enjoy RPGs with an emphasis on 3rd person action - not the other way around. The combat is fairly simple with a few nice twists, though certain combat styles are a touch overpowered while others feel heavily handicapped. If you're a gamer who looks for deep, challenging 3rd person combat, this isn't really what you're looking for. But it does offer rewards for people who are heavily into role-playing characters and only enjoy the action as a means to that end. Once I got a few of my combat skills ranked up enough, I started to feel like a serious Bond-level super-agent, which is exactly how I wanted to feel while playing.What Alpha Protocol brings to the table is a solid narrative with a few twists, a rich cast of interesting characters to inetract with, and a series of complicated moral quandries to navigate. The way you shape your character and his reactions makes a real difference in how the game feels - even if the levels you fight through are the same either way. Characters react to you differently depending on how you treat them (and others). I played through twice; once as a suave rookie agent in over his head, the next as a hard♥♥♥♥♥veteran willing to go to any lengths to get results. Each character felt unique, and my interactions with the NPCs felt different each time. My favorite parts of a great RPG are being able to shape a character, being surrounded by NPCs I care about or are interested in, and taking part in a story that grips me - or at least holds my interest while delivering enough surprises to keep me guessing. Alpha Protocol delivered that experience, along with a combat system that was fun and streamlined and made me feel like I was playing the kind of big screen super-spy I was hoping to create. So long as you go in without high expectations, but willing to overlook previous reviewers' complaints and have a fun time, I think you will. It was well worth it for me.

Posted: February 27, 2014
												This is probably the most inconsistent game I have ever played. It has its highlight moments where it's fantastic, but then it dumps total garbage moments on your lap and says 'deal with it'. I haven't finished the game yet (because I struggle - with what? you'll find out later) but so far the story is really tight. Global balance is at stake and it's your job to try and save the world from the imminent confilict. Alpha Protocol features a great Mass Effect-like dialogue wheel with limited time to response. This system forces you to make quick and usually hard decisions on the spot, which in turn makes converstations exciting and believable. There is also a system of reactions - the dialogue choices directly affect relationships with other characters - each individual is unique and responds vastly different to your actions. The relationships are meaningful and very useful where you are in the field - they have a genuine impact on the mission. In between missions you are in your hideout, where you can buy/sell equipments, trade valuable and sensitive intel (for instant embarassing information found during one of the missions concerning high ranking political figure - you can blackmail, sell to the highest bidder or hand over to the press), buy intel and help on your current mission and so forth. All of the above, this is where Alpha Protocol truly shines. Building your conntact networks, manipulating data, trying to find out as much as you can, talking with your partners - it all has its consequences and effects.Now for the bad part. The controls in this game are probably the poorest I have ever experienced. They are just a pain. Anyone who knows stealth games knows this - the controls have to be tight. In Alpha Protocol they are not. They are simply broken. That's why I strugle in this game. Unfortunately, it came to a point where I pretty much know how this game works and I sometimes have to exploit the game's wonkiness to advance. The AI acts weird. You can approach guard who is pretty much facing you and deliver a swift strike. Other times, the same guard would miraculously spot you and raise an alarm. But you know what the worst part of it is? The animations. To say the guards walk awkwardly is an understatment. They patrol areas and when they turn they occasionally pull off some unbelievable herky-jerky 360 move and spot you sneaking behind them. It's extremely frustrating. The level design is sometimes good, sometimes rather bad. In some areas (probably in general) the game favors certain paths of development (RPG-like skill points and abilities are here) and now I'm in a point where I have to use my martial arts skills, but I have none. Especially at the end of 'chapters' the game pits you against 'bosses' so to speak, and you have to engage them in an all-out gunfight. I was disappointed at this juncture, because it throws the whole 'stealth game' thing into a dumpster and becomes an unrefined shooter. Sadly, all of the negatives break the immersion and erase the joy of playing.This is a game with a great, albeit wasted potential. I'd really like to recommend it, because of a lot of superb ideas, but I cannot do this - Alpho Protocol will bring you more frustration than amusement and that's a shame. The thin stealth games market could have had a gem under its belt. TL;DR.If you are a diehard stealth-espionage fan, buy this, but be warned - Alpha Protocol is badly executed.

Posted: September 23, 2011
												Simply...uhm no...complex...awesome. Combining FPS with RPG and some deductive reasoning you take the role of a secret agent.I've seen more games like this, but what makes this my favourite is how you have to gather intel yourself before you go on a mission (corruption at the higher levels of your organization basically turns you into a fugitive), buy your hardware on the black market and apply your strategy.Sounds easy, but it really isn't, since you WILL encounter missions where you need to infiltrate allied organizations. They don't like that for obvious reasons, so all you can really do is make sure you kill nobody.I use a lot of tranquilizers for that but I can imagine a more experienced player can just sneak around unnoticed.Good music, great and DEEP storyline that makes the Bourne movies fade into nothing and a lot of flexibility in your approach. Too bad its built on the Unreal 3 engine...but I guess on Steam most FPS are either Source or Unreal 3....

Posted: February 27, 2014
												Alpha Protocol is the best spy RPG I've ever played (not that there are a ton of those games out there).The shooting is pretty good, and melee is a viable option unlike a lot of other shooter games. Stealth is a more challenging option, although the shooting is more fun.The game really shines with the dialog system, similar to Mass Effect but on a timer. The whole setup really makes you feel like you're actually Michael Thorton, actually talking to real people and making decisions based on how you interact with them. I'd go so far as to say it's the best dialog system I've ever seen in any game, let alone an action game.The visual character customization is ok. I like to stylize Mike for each type of mission I do. So when I go to Russia I look like a euotrash hipster. When I go to Saudi Arabia I look like a wealthy warlord prince, etc. Not a lot of action games give you that option.Probably the only negative thing I would say about it is that the mini-games (hacking, picking locks) get repetitive after a while, but still adds to the tension of the game, trying to hack into a computer and if you mess up, an alarm will sound.The closest game I can compare it to would be XIII. Playing with a gamepad is recommended.

Posted: March 23, 2014
												I've only played through two of the four operations so far in the game, but so far, I've enjoyed it immensely. Although the game totes itself as allowing the player to use different playstyles in order to progress, it is incredibly difficult to beat the game with a pure stealth build due to the boss fights that the player will inevitably come across. It took myself at least ten checkpoint loads in order to defeat the Russian mafia boss through the abuse of a low-leveled pistol skill that I had among the handful of higher leveled stealth skills that I had at my disposal (which were useless for anything other than for repositioning).Alpha Protocol is incredibly story driven where your conversations with the other characters in the game will affect future missions; if your handler doesn't like you, you get reduced mission bonuses and they will be less inclined to give you good information. Building and reading dossiers are also an important part for these conversations since it's possible to be intentionally mean to one character in order to boost your standing with another. You are warned in-game that a character that has too high of a good standing with you can potentially cause that person to act irrationally and cause problems for your missions, which is quite interesting.The combat is functional, but it doesn't really bring a ton of enjoyment. Stealthing the game is viable and you are rewarded if you sneak past enemies without taking them down (though you are also rewarded if you defeat/kill them). In fact, making it through missions undetected can affect future missions.It's something I'd recommend to those who enjoy espionage/thriller stories, though the game is not flawless.

Posted: November 9, 2015
												It took me some time to like this game since the animation was so clunky and dialogue was ridged as a porn shoot.This game is clearly a console port, but since it was a RPG where choices matter I kept playing and I’ll say once you get a hang of it then it’s a cool game. The customization from character and loadout is nice so I was always eager to tinker with the weapon attachments making them specialized for a specific mission.The dialogue system was interesting and different from any RPG game I’ve played. In Alpha Protocol all your responses are done in “real-time”. This means when NPC’s are done talking you’re meant to spontaneously respond to their statement. It confused me in the beginning, but since it forces you to select a response within 10 seconds you’ll have to go with your gut reaction making the communication between NPC’s more realistic.When you need to hack a computer you’re meant use the mouse and keyboard to drag some numbers over each other, it’s difficult to explain – but my point is that in this case the developers couldn’t be bothered to port this properly for the PC. When you’re hacking with the mouse it’s the clumsiest user experience you’ve experienced. I was close to uninstall it at that point, but gave it a chance!I still recommend this game!Peace.

Posted: November 10, 2015
												I first heard about this game from a list that was titled, "Best games you've (probably) never played". So naturally, I came into this game with mixed expectations. That said Alpha protocol has pleasantly surprised me. This is a stealth infiltration game. It's not a shooter, it's not even a traditional rpg per se. If you come expecting a shooter with great shooting mechanics or a deep RPG you will be dissapointed. On the other hand if you want a game that lets you play out your fantasies of being a modern day ninja, with a branching "choose your own adventure" style story. This game is right up your alley. It's core gameplay revolves around stealth, with minigames that involve keypad splicing, cracking safes, hacking pc terminals for various secret agenty reasons (gain intel, shut off surveillance cameras etc). It honestly reminds me of an American version of Metal Gear Solid with RPG lite elements that was never born. I liked it so much that I played it twice, back to back (I wanted to see how the story branches).If you've played everything else and are looking for something a little different. I highly recommend this gem.Edit: One thing I forgot. No support for 21:9 ultra widescreen monitors. At that resolution the UI is cut off on the top and bottom. After I changed my desktop resolution to a 16:9 ratio (1920x1080) it worked fine. That's the only bug/problem I encountered.

Posted: November 11, 2015
												Recommended, but with some caveat.If you have liked games from the Assassin's Creed, Batman-Arkham, or the Mass Effect series, chances are high you will like this infiltration/action/social interaction game (important: this is not a pure FPS game).That being said, this game would be second choice. I don't regret buying it, but I will very likely get tired of it before finishing it.On the pros side:The developers went out of their way to make the player feels that his choices have repercussions, be it from a tactical standpoint (rushing in all guns blazing is rarely a good choice, at least for my style of play, except when this is the better choice) or during the dialogues with other NPCs. More importantly, there is no real "good" choice. They have all potentially good or bad consequences, and you will have to live with them.The skill point system is somewhat unforgiving: in order to succeed at something, from hacking a computer to simply shooting a gun, the more points you have in the related skill, the better. So you have better to specialize. Except that sometimes, the needed action is not the action you specialized into. So you will have to reach a balance between specialization and versatility, with the few skill points you get awarded when your character level-up. This makes the game harder, but it helps with the immersion.There is a system of perks given as a reward for doing the same thing correctly many times (e.g. 20 hackings), or for having tried different things (e.g. answered someone in all 3 styles), or for having created a good relationship with your mission handler (or a bad relationship - it works, too). Each perk is either a one-time reward (100 XP, 1 skill point), or a permanent small benefit (5% discount on the black market), and even if each perk is a minor reward, by their quick accumulation it's making the game more enjoyable. It feels very rewarding, because the game is basically telling you, you are doing something right.This is a game where it is theoritically possible to do a "pacifist run", albeit that could be a wee bit challenging at time. The game is compiling two helpful values to judge your agressiveness: hospital bills (for non-lethal neutralisations) and number of orphans (yep, for hard kills). Feel free to maximize whichever value you prefer. Choices and consequences, as I said.There is a definite gritty aspect in the atmosphere of the game. You are playing an operativegood at manipulating others (the "manipulating" is right there in your dossier, said your boss) in a "the end justifies the means" shadow agency, and your allies are certainly no angels (from coldly practical to downright sadists). For many players who are looking for a "realistic" spy/infiltration game, this has a strong appeal.Which brings me to the cons side.The occasional sadistic choices will sometimes leave me with a very bad feeling; if you prefer to play goodie characters, this game may not be for you.An extreme example is when you catch an arm dealer in the first chapter. You can either kill him on the spot, arrest him, or let him bribe you and escape. With the first two, you lose access to some weapons and mods on the black market until the next chapter (and apparently, the baddies as well, so it's not that bad). If you let him go, you get a discount on the local black market, but the baddies are better equiped and the TV news will hammer you with the body count of a terrorist attack on a local US army base. But, eh, choices and consequences, deal with it. So far, so good.That got under my skin in this instance is that happened when I decided to arrest him (in a first game, I let him go). My choice decreased the local terrorist activities, my operative got congratulations from his handlers and I got a "Due process" perk as a reward. And then the game told me repeatedly, in no uncertain terms, that the poor sod I arrested was headed for the torture chamber. And this godamnit operative I have been guiding for a few hours to sneak in and minimize casualties was totally unapolegetic about it. Quite cheerful about it, he was, actually. It thrashed my good feelings over an otherwise successful mission. And talk about "due process". The expression "bitter ashes of victory" comes to mind.Storywise, it is a good reminder of the context and the "game" being played. As I said, gritty atmosphere and hard choices, the spy business is no job for the meek. One damning point is that, still storywise, this bout of torture is totally un-necessary: you get the info you need and around $15,000 in cash with whichever choice you made. If making the player aware of all of the amoral/immoral subtext in the spy business was the objective of the developers, I should commend them on this. Gamewise, my point is that this sort of situation may result in divorcing you from your character. If you want to play a somewhat moral character trying to do a clean job, forget it. It's a messy job about to get messier, and he is a jerk in a world of jerks.Another big default of this game is the aphazard mouse control. Regularly, when combat starts, I found myself aiming at the sky or the opposite direction because the mouse overreacted to my frantic attempts at aiming. Similarly, during hacking minigames, the code I'm busy slotting in a precise spot will go sideway when I click it home, often trigering the alarm. Conversely, in the lockpicking minigame, I will spend a good 10 s (out of the 15-20 alloted) pushing the mouse up again and again until the first part of the lock deigns to move up in the right position.Part of these controlling issues may actually be a designed part of the game, as my mouse control gets better as I pour more skill points in the relevant skill (see the skill point section above); and in this case having no point in a skill is harshly punitive indeed. And part of these issues may just be me being me, a player of average skill and motor control. Still, I feel that the mouse sensitivity could have been better adjusted between the different parts of the game.My difficulties at controlling the mouse during gunfight is actually one big reason why I prefer the silent, close-combat approach.
