Posted: July 15, 2014
												Alpha Protocol is an enjoyable game but not without its flaws. The game is made by Obsidian and it would probably be fair to call it a sort of "James Bond Mass Effect." An interesting thing about the game is the way dialogue plays out. Unlike most RPGs that have a system where you can choose your own dialogue, you don't have an unlimited amount of time to pick your responses. You must choose to be one of the three "JB" prototypes the designers based the main character off of - Suave, like James Bond, Professional, like Jason Bourne, or Aggressive like Jack Bauer. Your choices feel like they impact the story more than similar choices in other games, though there are (I think) only three endings.As for actually carrying out your missions, the game plays like a third person shooter. Ultimately, there is little point in investing in skills outside of stealth and pistols for your first play through, as those are the over powered skills in the game. In fact, some bosses you might find near impossible without the pistol's special skill. Even with stealth skills, you might find it difficult to perfectly stealth certain missions. Running and gunning isn't really a very viable option on a first playthrough because most of the weapons require you to focus your aim on a target to get a critical hit (it kind of reminds me of the first Deus Ex, where you stay stationary with your reticle over a target until your shot lines up perfectly). There are a couple different minigames for hacking, lock picking, and disabling alarms and the like. The only one that kinda gave me problems was the hacking mini game, back when I first tried this game on the XBox 360. The way it works is, you have two sequences of alpha numeric characters that must be lined up on a screen of constantly changing alpha numerics (it kinda looks like the "code" in the Matrix movies, if that makes any sense). The bit you're trying to match will be static, so it's kind of a test of your eyesight and almost like a "Where's Waldo" thing. If you don't do it fast enough, the static bit of code will randomly change to another location, and then if you completely run down the timer you set off an alarm. It's been a LITTLE while since I played the game but I believe if you abort the hack before the timer runs down you can get another attempt or two depending on your skill and the difficulty of the hack.The game is fairly nonlinear, even from the start. You have the option of completing the tutorial missions for bonus XP, perks, etc or going straight into the missions. In the first locale you are given the choice of what missions to tackle when, and you can complete the "main" mission before finishing up all the side missions. Once the game branches out after the first mission, you can globe trot and handle the missions in any order you please, which can impact your relations with characters and change the parameters for other missions and unlock certain boss fights and so on. You definitely won't see all there is to see in the game in a single play through. If you beat the game on "Recruit" difficulty you unlock "Veteran" mode which gives you a whole slew of skill points at the start to play around with. It's not quite a New Game + but fairly similar.Alpha Protocol seems to be a love it or hate it kind of a game. If you can get past the gameplay quirks it's very enjoyable, and I'd definitely recommend picking it up. It seems to go on sale often so throw it on your wishlist and snag it at a good price!Final Score = 7.5/10

Posted: July 1, 2013
												mmmmm.... so secret agents, 007 like moments, girls from around the world, and a corporation that is planning to control the world through fear of a cold war and now your agent is the only person who can stop them. Yeah Alpha Protocol has all these things, but jokes aside AP is actually a pretty fun game to play. AP's combat is not very unique but yet still satisfying to go through an area without anyone seeing you. But the combat is not what the heart of the game is; instead it's actually the choice's your character makes that defines the game. There is no good or bad choice only result's and it's these choices that defines who your character is by the end of the game. Every character you meet has a different personality and therefor reacts differently towards what you say, this in turn will affect how your 'handler' works with you on missions but the game can explain all of this better than me. If you haven't guessed this already Alpha Protocol is a must buy for anyone who's tired of these stupid Bond games and instead want to be an agent. While there are a few frustrating moments like the checkpoints or the wired loading thing how it affects the camera but these are a very small things that should not turn you off from buying this game. Overall Alpha Protocol is game that will make you enjoy your time while playing the game.

Posted: July 16, 2014
												Alpha Protocol can be frustrating as hell at times but it’s well worth a play through. The story is very reactive to the player’s choices as far as I can tell, with your alliances and the outcomes of your missions drastically altering how the story plays out. Your actions outside of dialogues carry weight too; even how you deal with enemies can lead to different outcomes.The combat is decent. It’s a little clunky and could have done with a bit more polish, but it does get the job done. And I have to admit there’s a certain level of satisfaction when you manage to stealth your way through an area by using the Chain Shot ability. Speaking of the abilities, there isn’t much variety in them. I think the game could have done with some more skills to use.The character customization also isn't very good. You're stuck with a specific character and can barely alter his appearance, only being able to change his hair, beard, skin tone, eye color, glasses, and hat, all of which only have a few options. I think more customization of Thorton would have been good. All in all, it’s worth a look. Just don’t pay more than $10 for it, don’t expect some AAA Mass Effect quality, and keep in mind it's a stealth/action game first and an RPG second.

Posted: August 28, 2014
												Alpha Protocol suffered from numerous delays and was still released very buggy, which at the time made playing the game rather frustrating. The current build is stable, resource-lean and largely bug-free, however.The game has three major focuses: Stealth, combat, and dialogue. The first two are serviceable, though games like Thief or Deus Ex leave AP far in the dust. Players familiar with more comprehensive stealth games will likely be weirded out by some of the design choices, such as the linear area designs, or the guards in a given sub-area disappearing once you've moved onto the next, even if you can go back to the first -- though often you can't, as doors mysteriously lock up behind you. Combat likewise feels rather clunky, though I myself usually prefer the stealthy approach, anyhow -- almost all combat aside from boss fights can be avoided, as can be killing enemies even when you DO decide to engage them. The game offers various lethal and nonlethal methods of dealing with enemies.It's in story and dialogue where the game, which is first and foremost an RPG, really shines. Many missions consist of nothing but dialogue, and virtually every choice you make therein has some consequence in gameplay, as do the actions you take. The effect might be slight, such as increasing or decreasing a character's opinion of you (something that may well come into play later on), or it might open up or close off entire story paths. How the end game plays out very much depends on the choices you made and how you interacted with the various characters you meet along the way.The dialogue is witty and flows along effortlessly, and the characters are interesting, varied and written in depth. Beside the dialogue, there's also tons of documents for the player to uncover and delve into, and acquiring this extra data often offers all kinds of story benefits as well. In short, it is a real treat for anyone fond of story-driven RPGs.

Posted: May 29, 2014
												This game is buggy, the animations are mediocre, the combat can be repetitive, and the AI can be quite dumb at times. That said, Alpha Protocol comes extremely close to being an almost perfect game, and this is carried in large part due to it's incredible branching storyline. I find that too many games these days give a false sense of choice, and their impacts to the narrative. In this game, your choices matter, you have very little time to make these choices, and every choice you make impacts the story greatly. It's a shame we may never see a sequel to this game. Overall, I would give Alpha Protocol a solid 8/10, and that's with all of it's baggage.

Posted: February 23, 2016
												A definite buy on sale. You could replay the game twice and still want to play it again because of the countless choices in skill masteries all inviting numerous styles of play that do not get tiresome. Though the story does not stand out, the locations and level design compensate. While we as players have been spoiled with richer storylines in the past decade, the game has a way with displaying a variety of story choices that makes you care about where its going. You'll begin to care about the direction of the story and the relationships you want to foster without the game. And, after its all said and done, you might just do it all over again to explore the relationships you missed out on.TL;DR: Pull the trigger if you're looking for an Action RPG that will pleasantly surprise you in story, skill choice, and environments.

I have to say it is very well done my only real gripe is a personal one as the main character has the same name as a boss I had working for a roofing company who cheated me out of a substantiel amount of money and tools...all that aside...ProsGreat actionGreat StoryAwesome weaponsGood customization all the way aroundSlew of gadgetsGreat choice system during dialogues.Sense of being a "burned" agent is pretty heavyMovie quality twists and turns.Great character growthConsCombat can seem rushed "As in the enemies will sometimes stop and do nothing"like the A.I is too genericThe puzzles may be too hard for some "I think they are fine"The focus "aiming" system requires some getting use to and doesn't relie totally on your own judgement.No multiplayer or coop "think that would have made this game a legend despite some of its flaws"Sometimes the game seems more like a parody then serious buisness as the story is seemingly serious yet some of the events or things happening seem almost campy.closing statement...Alpha Protocol is simply amazing 10/10 and if you like spy games where speechcraft,espionage and intel are essential then this is a game for you. Posted: February 5, 2014
												Alpha Protocol is an espionage RPG that does a few things pretty well.  The conversation mechanic is pretty good for a  port, and the story was interesting enough to keep me interested through my first playthrough.  Its biggest strength is how flexible the game is regarding your choices and style.  There are consequences to certain choices, to be sure, but none that should make you throw up your hands and reload due to missed content.  The combat and stealth are serviceable--nothing great if you're used to smooth stealth games like the original Splinter Cell trilogy.  I definitely recommend playing with a 360 controller over K+M.The glaring problem with this console-to-PC port is the HORRENDOUS loading bugs.  They are well-established across multiple operating systems.  If you die, you can either choose "Reload Last Save" with a high liklihood of game-killing bugs or manually choose a save with an approximately 70% chance that you will get a black screen that you must Alt-Tab and close.  This alone leads me to recommend that you get in on a compatible console if you own one or only buy it when deeply discounted.

Posted: March 24, 2014
												9/10 is the Best rating i can give this game, its succeeds with flying colors, the combat is fluid for the most part (a few hiccups where you can shoot the enemies at times but they can't shoot you) in skill system is good and well balanced but even with doing every side objective and mission you won't be able to max out the 3 skill trees you choose to expand on after the first mission is successful (Operation Desert Spear) the characters are likeable, and you have to STAY ON YOUR TOES. How you treat characters can be used against you for both good and ill, wether you go in Guns a blazing or you prefer to do stealth,  it is a fanstastic game, while there would be a few different things i would change (adding in a NEW GAME+ option would be nice so you could experiment with the different tiers of guns 0*-3*, adding in a few extra missions in each of the 4 areas would be nice too.) Other than that though i honestly have no regrets about the game it is by FAR a great example of 3rd person spy RPG though and it is well worth the money to pick it up, will last you about 16 hours the first time.A side note, i use pistols and rifles, mainly due to the fact that the Silencer Mk3 has no damage drop off, and the first 2* pistol except damage has some of the higher stats in the game for the pistols (i prefer Recoil control, Accuracy, Stability, etc. over just Damage as you can easily boost Damage with equipment) I choose Freelancer and Operative as i like to customize my play experience from the begining rather than having my skills pre chosen for me.

Posted: March 30, 2014
												I was on the ropes about this game due to mixed reviews about it, but happened to get it on a good sale so figured why not and see what happens. I was both impressed and frustrated with the game. Some of the base setup is like Mass Effect (for those who have played it) as you select your background consisting of soldier, field agent and tech specialist, freelancer, recruit and veteran (you have to unlock this by playing through the game as a recruit first). They all start out differently with their stats (though recruit starts with no points at all while the veteran is polar opposite, having three points in all fields) but can be customized the way you want prior to beginning the story.During conversations with NPCs you are given a a few different reponses to choose from, these responses are broken down into types such as professional, sarcastic, aggressive, suave, etc. and depending on which path you take can result in people liking or disliking you. This introduces an element where you can gain bonuses from the character if they happen to like you such as additional intel, support, or bonuses to your abilities. It also makes the game worth replaying to see how things can change up.The main theme of the game is to play as a spy, but it gives you the options to take things through stealthfully, guns blazing or a little bit of both. The RPG elements add a twist to the gameplay as you can get skills to help take down multiple enemies in an instant, evade prying eyes for a brief period so you can slip into a proper hiding location and become more proficient with your equipment. You can also buy better weapons and armor as well as mods for your equipment to improve them in specific fields (though some of them also carry a downside). Now as nice as these elements are, they come with some issues. The biggest issue I found was the camera can be rather finicky, making precition aiming difficult at times, especially while trying to use a sniper rifle. However there are some threads out there that will help fix this issue, but they aren't a 100% fix, just makes things more managable. One of the mini-games also suffers from awkward controls since you have to control the set of numbers using both your keyboard and mouse. The set controled by the mouse suffers from positioning issues which has screwed me a number of times as it would shift position just before a click to confirm the code. This became less of a problem when adjusting the games settings for smooth out the camera. Another issue is sometimes when you reload after dying, triggers aren't reset and units won't spawn in. Had this happen once near the end of the game and couldn't progress because the helicopter that killed me had to blow open the gate blocking my path. Or sometimes units are respawned even though they were taken out before the checkpoint, leaving you with enemies behind you which may or may not bite you.The dialogue and voice acting is, for the most part, pretty good. There are times where the dialogue comes off poorly, mainly due to the person reading the lines. Most of this happens to come from Thortan's character where he has a number of lines that come off really bland or awkward, but he does have a large number of really well delivered lines both in the humour and professional departments (haven't really played him as an aggressive "shoot first, care never" type of character yet, but it's on my to-do list).Overall the game is rather entertaining. It would have been nice if they provided more side missions to do or even provided a new game plus (seriously, all RPG's should support this just so that players can have a little extra fun with the abilities, mainly so they don't have to modify the game just to screw around). If you're looking for an action RPG or even a spy themed game and don't mind RPG elements, give it a good. Hopefully later down the road Obsidian will think of making another Alpha Protocol and maybe even work out the kinks that made the game a bit frustrating at times.

Posted: July 10, 2011
												Forget what the reviews say. Sure, it's an Obsidian game, so there are bound to be a few bugs. But: it's an Obsidian game, and that means it's excellently written, and tons of fun to play. It really deserves a sequel, even though it's an excellent game in its own right (and no, there's no cliffhanger ending; it's wrapped up at the end). Think of it this way: it combines the brilliant writing/dialogue of Planescape, with the gameplay of Deus Ex, in third person. For the most part, it pulls this off brilliantly. Keep in mind that one playthrough of this game is going to be different from the next: how you interact with people determines how the story plays out, and will open up various different missions and plots, so multiple playthroughs are definitely worth it. After reading the reviews, I went into this game a bit skeptical, but I've become a convert. Buy this game!!

Posted: September 10, 2015
												Obsidian Entertainment specializes in following Bioware's footsteps closely. In this case, they didn't get an explicit deal to do a sequel for a Bioware game, so instead what we have is something with plot structure, dialogue design, and combat fairly closely modeled after Mass Effect. Unfortunately it's modeled after Mass Effect 1, from before Bioware had really worked out how to do first person shooting, and as an added problem the modern setting means that the special powers you can learn are almost universally pretty lame. To make the power system worse, they have individual cooldowns but using more than one in succession requires pausing the game and opening a menu.The stealth component is all about patiently following people around as they walk slooowly about and then bonking them in the throat.Running around with two uzis and leet karate skillz was reasonably fun though, good enough to breeze around the battlefields from amusing dialogue session to amusing dialogue session. All in all, as with other Obsidian games, I would recommend this to people who have played the Bioware version it's based on and want some more.

												Do you like espionage RPGs that gives you choices, and makes impacts on the storyline and gameplay based on said choices? Then Alpha Protocol is for you!The GameIn the game, you follow the protagonist spy Mike Thorton, who's newly recruited into an agency program called Alpha Protocol. Thorton is sent on a mission in Saudi Arabia to kill Shaheed, the leader of a feared terrorist group Al Samad, as a retaliation response to them shooting down a commercial airlines plane.After having dealt with the insurgents however, things change for the worse and Mike Thorton is forced to become a rogue agent and uncover an evil plot from an american corporation, where he has to travel to Taipei, Rome and Moscow in order to gather intel and allies.The Ups+ Story   I found that the story was the most interesting part of Alpha Protocol, and was the biggest reason I kept playing through it. The game does an excellent job putting in twists to the story. The shady characters are often not as bad as you perceive, and the innocent characters are often more than they seem to be. + Stealth   Some reviewers had issues with the stealth in this game, though I experienced few problems with it. The game did feel a bit too linear at points, even though you had several points of entry to an objective, which made the stealth gameplay in those areas a bit less enjoyable, however overall I had great fun playing as a sneaky spy with maxed stealth abilities. *Hint: Shadow Operative is OP*+ Choices Matter   The choices you make in this game, and your decision on whether to go guns blazing into an objective, or take the non-lethal stealth approach without casualties has an impact on the storyline and gameplay. If you decided to take on an objective head on, Rambo-style, your next mission may have more security stationed around.+ Scenery   There's a nice change of scenery between Taipei, Rome, Moscow and Saudi Arabia, making each location feel refreshing enough and you get to go to a new area, before you start to get bored of the aesthetics in the old place.+ Email system   After every mission, you'll be checking your computer for emails containing story, dialogue, intel, etc. You get the option to reply to several characters, and some of the replies you can make are pretty fun and adds humor to the seriousness. You also get the chance to blackmail corporations, or choose to expose them in the media.+ Play as you like   With a diverse 'skilltree' you can choose whether you want to become an expert at stealth, sabotage, if you want to be a gunslinger with pistols, a close-up commando agent with shotguns, SMGs, and assault rifles, or be an expert martial arts fighter with nonlethal takedowns. The choice is yours!.. And The Downs - Minigames   When it comes to hacking, sabotaging or lockpicking, you will have to go through a minigame. These are annoying boring chores that you will encounter several times in each mission. Lockpicking is easy on PC, with sabotaging getting harder and especially hacking being a challenge. Thankfully if you don't enjoy these parts, you can stock up on EMPs and blaze through these sections, completely bypassing the minigames altogether. That's what I did when it came to hacking.  - Camera twitching   With this game being a console port, you will encounter camera twitching when you move your mouse around. After one hour gameplay, I had to search for a fix on this issue, as it was close to gamebreaking on my end. The good news; There's a fix for it! The bad news; I don't remember where I found it.- Combat   Combat in this game is mostly boring, and your guns are very (and I mean very) inaccurate unless you lock onto a target for an extended amount of time. The combat system takes some time to get used, but is less of a problem once you get accustomed to how it works, along with you putting more Ability Points into a weapon type. I went with Stealth and Pistol, being able to one hit K.O enemies from stealth, and using the ability Chain Shot on bosses for a fast and easy kill.- Dialogue options   I don't mind you only having a little time to reply during conversations, as that adds tension, but I dislike the system where you're only allowed to choose in what 'mood' you reply in. Do you wanna answer in a professional, aggressive or suave kind of way? I've chosen one 'mood' on several occasions and had my agent Thorton spit out some stupid crap I would never have picked in the first place. I prefer the Mass Effect style of dialogue instead of the way they're doing it in this game.The ResumeI wasn't expecting much from playing Alpha Protocol, but it actually surprised me. It has it's ups and down, especially with the combat. Having played through it now, I would most likely have bought it for the original price tag on Steam. If you're unsure whether or not this game might be fun for you, I can definitely recommend buying it through a sale, as it has several hours of gameplay and replayability to it, if you wish to see the story from different perspectives!

Posted: September 14, 2015
												Many games claim that "your choices matter" and "no two playthroughs are identical" and any number of other things which boil down to "player choice matters." Reactivity. Call  it whatever - most games don't deliver.Alpha Protocol does.It's not perfect. It's a console port with console-port-itis, imperfect balance, odd controls. AP doesn't get really good until after your first hub, and it doesn't become amazing unless you play it twice and see just how much reactivity it has. That's a lot of time to invest in a flawed title. It's not for everyone.In the end, Obsidian tried for a great game and they didn't quite make it ... but they sure came close.

Posted: September 19, 2015
												This is one of those games that got lost in the shuffle. Possibly overshadowed by another release or maybe poor advertising campaign.  Pay no attention to the fact that I've played it for a mere 5hrs - I OWN this on DVD from a while ago and have beaten the game several times. In fact it's the first game I've played since Never Winter Nights that inspired me to replay immediately after the end. Literally I started over when it ended.  --  The replayability comes from the fact that you can never know the true intentions of ANY of the people you deal with unless you have gathered all the Intel on them... and you can NEVER get all the intel on everyone in one playthrough.   (To clearify: You can get ALL the intel on one person but you'll sacrifice the option to get intel on another person in doing so) It was interesting finding out that I supported the wrong people for what I *thought* were the right reasons on my second time through (by making different choices from the first playthrough and gathering different Intel)The Game mechanics are NOT all that great and it lends itself to possible exploitation when chosing skill sets -- If you max out Pistols and a couple other skills you can actually shoot "blind" (without aiming) from cover and get headshots about 80% of the time.  --  You can compensate for this flaw by playing on a harder level or diversifying your skillset to include other weapons thereby reducing the possibility of maxing a skill.Overall I recommend this to anyone who likes a cool spy story.

Posted: August 22, 2015
												I absolutly love this game. Don't let my low hours fool you, I also own it on console and have beaten it multible times. It's something fairly unique being basically the only Spy game in the RPG-Shooter genre. The choices you make actually have effects on how people react to you and the character upgrades are well done.

Posted: September 5, 2015
												Very clever dialogs and interesting story, the graphics are good even on todays standards, combat system is not the best one but it's not bad like some people say. Its accurate and flowing, much better than in Mass Effect 1 (which is good game to compare, as it share many same elements). Mass Effect came before Alpha Protocol so some people will say AP tries to be like ME by using same style conversation system and gamestyle, actually in Alpha Protocol the converastion system is much better than in Mass Effects, you get 5-10 seconds to answer and if you wait too long the protagonist will use the default answer automatically, this is something that many story based games should copy, it's great idea.9/10

Posted: August 13, 2011
												Alpha Protocol is an ambitious game which is flawed, but also great in what it accomplishes. It is a spy RPG where you play a rogue agent.  It takes choice and consequence longer than any other game I know of, the branching storyline is huge. A character which for one player becomes a valuable ally can be a mortal enemy for another, and a third player never met this character. Dialogue is timed, you only one or two seconds to select an answer which creates more tension than most other game's boss fights. Download the latest patches though, I don't know if they are included in Steam.Tip: The first levels are the most poorly designed, and combat and sneaking is unsatisfying here too, but keep going, once you get past Saudi Arabia the game world opens up, you can travel the world, and you will have some skill points invested which makes gameplay more enjoyable.

Posted: September 22, 2014
												For those who are sceptical about this game, do yourself a favor and play it. Its totally worth your time.This game keeps your attention the whole time, and after the end, you will want to play this game again.You are Agent Thorton, and you have a mission. It is up to you to decide what to do after that mission.Your choices have consequences, good and bad. You want something? Maybe you will lose another!Well, the game have a poor gameplay, with some stupid bugs, but for me, nothing important because it is really funny to play it, and it have a RPG component, which makes this game a little bit more interesting.The storyline behind this game is really interesting too, and makes you think about the actual political state of our planet.This game has drama, romance, comedy, and some memorable characters. You can choose. The game is built by you.Now, go play this. You will enjoy!

												This game was TWO DORRAR! Worth every penny.

Posted: September 10, 2015
												Obsidian Entertainment specializes in following Bioware's footsteps closely. In this case, they didn't get an explicit deal to do a sequel for a Bioware game, so instead what we have is something with plot structure, dialogue design, and combat fairly closely modeled after Mass Effect. Unfortunately it's modeled after Mass Effect 1, from before Bioware had really worked out how to do first person shooting, and as an added problem the modern setting means that the special powers you can learn are almost universally pretty lame. To make the power system worse, they have individual cooldowns but using more than one in succession requires pausing the game and opening a menu.The stealth component is all about patiently following people around as they walk slooowly about and then bonking them in the throat.Running around with two uzis and leet karate skillz was reasonably fun though, good enough to breeze around the battlefields from amusing dialogue session to amusing dialogue session. All in all, as with other Obsidian games, I would recommend this to people who have played the Bioware version it's based on and want some more.

Posted: September 9, 2015
												Only done one playthrough so far, and even though I was warned that the plot would take a few big twists, I was happily suprised by each one. I had the distinct feeling that choices I made mattered to a huge degree, and I'm confident that future playthroughs will end up quite different based on key decisions. I look forward to seeing what changes and challenges await in future games! 9/10.*Edit*: I see some people saying that the XBOX controller is necessary for a good game experience but I'd like to disagree with that. I almost always play FPS with a controller but mine is currently lent to a friend, so I decided to just give it a try with the keyboard and mouse and it certainly felt different than what I'm used to and I could tell it was designed to be played with a controller but I didn't feel crippled or even that hindered that I wasn't using one.

Posted: July 4, 2015
												This game is fantastic.  While the combat is a little janky and feels a little undercooked, overall it does more right than wrong.  I didn't like the combat at first, but I got used to it and it got better as I played by upgrading my stats and gaining abilities.  The narrative and choice structure is really the highlight.  It really feel like the story progresses fluidly based on your decisions, who you ally with and who you don't.  These decisions effect things including conversations you have later, who assists you, who you can romance, and of course the ending.  I would recommend this to anyone who wants something a little different from a typical CoD action game.

Posted: February 22, 2014
												I went into this game with quite high expectations. Obsidian is arguably my favorite video game company, and the guys who worked on Alpha Protocol are also some of my favorite devs and writers. But I got something completely different.This game tries to be new in many ways, and fails in all of them. And I do say this with a heavy heart, because I love sneaking games. The Metal Gear Solid series are some of my favorite games, and in any RPG I can be a rogue or a thief I chose that on the spot. But Alpha Protocol should have spent more time thinking about the gameplay instead of polishing the story. The controls in this game are beyond horrible, I lost count of how many times I accidently slipped out of cover because I wanted to look around, or ran from soldiers only to hit a random invisible wall and get gunned down. It's a very easy game, but the sheer chaos of the controls alone makes it extremely hard, but not in a good way. In an infuriating way, where you know what you need to do, and you know how to do it, you just need to make the game understand it, and it refuses to do so. Unfortunately I have to downvote this game and throw a review as a warning: Don't. Go play Metal Gear Solid instead. It's what this tries to be, but fails.

Posted: August 19, 2015
												First let me promise you that while it's sometimes difficult to play with keyboard and mouse, you will get used to it after an hour or two.  It's worth it.Contrary to what you might expect from Obsidian, the game is NOT unfinished or plagued with bugs.  It's also not as ambitious, only taking 20 hours to beat, but I can't complain about that when it's so cheap now and it has a lot of replay value.Don't expect a great story with lots of unexpected twists and turns.  Let's just say it owes a LOT to the Bourne movies.  From the first few minutes of the game it's pretty clear who the villains are and they never get any interesting or believable motives for their actions.  It's also not the best shooter, stealth game, or RPG that you can find.  But just like Mass Effect, the different elements of the game fit together well and the whole is better than the sum of its parts.  Besides, where else can you find a game that actually makes you feel like you're in a spy movie?

Posted: August 12, 2015
												Action can be a bit clunky at times, but the systems make a lot of sense once you've spent some time with them. Story is standard fare for the genre, but does well at keeping you interested, and can branch quite significantly depending on your choices. The game doesn't really give you enough time with any character to grow connected, and the player's tone can change quite severely within any one conversation depending on dialogue choice, which can be jarring. Although this review may seem critical, I couldn't put the game down. It is well worth the current price of £9.99. If Alpha Protocol appears in a Steam Sale, you should have no qualms about picking it up.

Posted: June 5, 2013
												Ignore the haters: Alpha Protocol, in spite of its many rough edges, is an incredibly engaging game with a truly fast-paced and exciting story. Yes, it's buggy as all hell, but it's easily Obsidian's finest work as of late. Posted: July 7, 2015
												Pros:- Unique take on dialogue trees (essentially timed to keep the conversation flowing).- Minigames (hacking, lockpicking, etc.) are well designed and timed as well.- Decent amount of customization.- Good level design.- Great dynamic between Player and other characters. Having downsides to characters liking you and upside to characters hating you actually makes the good/bad choices carry a lot of weight, even if indirectly.- Fluid and intuitive controls in firefights.Cons:- A.I. is buggy- Some animations (enemy strafing, turning around) are nonexistent.- In game dialogue will overpower any other sound, and cutscene dialogue will be overshadowed by music.- Bland music.- Close contact with A.I. (silent kills, melee) will glitch out. A lot.- Controls are not as well oriented for stealth as they should be.- Dialogue choices are summarized in onw word which also counts as a pro for being different but it makes it really hard to know what the game means by its word choice.I won't mention story/plot cause I haven't finished the game yet.Recommended ONLY if you have no problem with bugs. None are game-breaking, but you will notice them.

Posted: July 1, 2015
												I bought this game for a steal and figured if it was bad, oh well, $2 down the crapper. Instead, I was surprised by the depth and complexity of this admittedly flawed gem. Other reviews have mentioned the two biggest flaws: upgraded stealth is overpowered while open combat is pretty bad, and the conversation option you choose doesn't necessarily align with what comes out of your character's mouth. Instead, let me mention the game's two main strengths. - The protagonist. He's a♥♥♥♥♥♥ but he's your♥♥♥♥♥♥ you can make him aggressive, sleazy, cowardly, whatever. It's a real change of pace to play a game in which the player character isn't (a) a gruff, patriotic super-soldier or (b) Our Lord and Savior. - The choices. Too many RPGs reduce player choice to a black-and-white, good vs evil dichotomy (looking at you, Mass Effect) or have no weight because their effects are minimal or nonexistent (that's you, Elder Scrolls). In Alpha Protocal,  every single choice is morally grey; there's no copping out and always picking the Paragon option. And your choices have results: key characters live or die, and there are missions you may or may not undertake based on conversation options alone. It's a lot like the Witcher games in that regard. Hell, you can sleep with and kill every female in the game. Lastly, Turn Up the Radio will never sound the same.

Posted: July 2, 2015
												Its awkward, buggy and mechanically ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ at times, but my God, the reactive world and all the consequences totally immerse you in the spy world of Alpha Protocol. Everything you do during gameplay or during converstions with people genuinely shapes the relationships of the people around you and whether or not you even get to meet certain people/find that evidence/have that mission available. The consequences can sometimes have huge effects on the direction of the story and sometimes a character might just off handedly mention something you did (positively or negatively). Its that nuance that makes it so impressive. Why arent other developers copying this level of complexity ????If you can get past the opening level and get to the first big story moment you are going to play one of the most under-rated RPG's around. Just dont expect amazing levels of polish. On this occassion Obsideon lost their can of Mr Sheen !!!

Posted: July 1, 2015
												Could have been the next Mass Effect but....it suffered from being released without being polished. It had many bugs that have since been patched and it still suffers from poor AI, occasional camera issues, unbalanced gameplay and some awkward animations but overall this game had huge potential and could have been the first in a series of incredible games like we've see in the mass effect series. Many people have criticized the shooting controls. First of all you need to level up the variuous weapon skills to make the guns better and more accurate. Secondly the game is not a shooter at heart it is an RPG, more like mass effect 1 was. I really enjoy leveling up hand to hand in this game, you will be beating enemies down like a martial arts master. It's fun. Thats one of the good things about this game. You can play it any way you want. Go stealthy, brawler or all guns blazing. The choice is yours.AP is actually alot like Mass Effect. So if you liked Mass Effect give this game a try. There's a lot of choice that effects how the game plays out. It has a lot of variety to the missions that I find to be better than some of Mass Effect's missions.  It uses the Unreal engine and looks quite nice for the time it was released. There are also some tweeks you can search on google to make it look even better if you want. Turn off motion blur at least, it's not good in this game.Its a shame that the game didn't get fine tuned before release because I think it was a good game and could have been a great franchise. Unfortunately the game was released as a buggy mess and deserved the low review scores it got. Even with Alpha Protocols flaws I recommend you get the game. It's worth playing and really cheap now. I hope obsidian or sega makes Alpha Protocol 2 but I doubt thats going to happen.

Posted: June 22, 2015
												Third-Person shooter/Stealth game with heavy RPG elements.The game has a strong narrative focus and enjoyable stealth and gunplay.The complex dialogue trees and smoothly integrated sidequests are the main replay value, as the rookie and veteran builds have their own dialogue options.Character advancement is fluid, and the high-level skills become overkill in many cases (eg: Chain Shot + Brilliance), while others become virtually essential (eg: Stealth and Infiltrator paths).Perks are interesting and well-implemented, and feel rewarding for trying different approaches to missions.The game is not without flaws, though.Movement and platforming feels restrictive, specially when compared to pure action 3d platformers.Cover also feels rigid, as some walls and objects don't allow you to hide behind or require you to approach at the right angle or distance to activate the option.Gunsights are not pinpoint acccurate, which leads to a certain frustration during fights, as bullets go stray all the time.Stealth is consistent enough, but tends to shift infrequently, making enemies spot you while on their blind sides some times and not reacting to you in front of them at others.The assault riffle only shoots 3-round bursts. It would've been awesome if you could use one-shot and auto-fire modes.But these flaws are not that significative, since the game is not meant to be an action shooter, full-on stealth or 3d platformer, but a narrative RPG where you can take multiple approaches to challenges.Gameworld design is more linear than comparable games like Deus Ex: Human Revolution, but is still open enough to allow multiple approaches to the same objectives most of the time.Dialogues are smooth and flow seamlessly, with nice voice acting. The in-mission chat with the controller adds to the experience, and the limited time to choose replies during conversation adds a degree of challenge to "cutscenes".Intrigue storyline is interesting and engaging, and changes according to what you did (or didn't) during previous missions, where you've been and who you've met before.Graphics feel a little dated for 2015, but that's a natural byproduct of technological advancement.

Posted: July 25, 2015
												Alpha Protocol is one of the few games I would label as a jack of all trades. The game lets you live out an adventure in the life of a secret agent, providing ample opportunities to play as you see fit. The gameplay varies playthrough to playthrough, and allows you to complete a level with either heavy firepower or the more difficult and rewarding stealth approach. It falls short in that while it does provide a huge variety of ways to play the game, the parts that you do end up picking lead up to an average to mediocre third person shooter. The storyline is very similar to Mass Effect as in you pick dialogue choices which effect the story later on. It isn't actually too bad if you enjoy the sort of over the top Bond-esque action adventure. This game is good for those who enjoy a non-linear first person shooter, or those that are fans of the Splinter Cell franchise.

Posted: July 23, 2015
												No idea why this game got bad reviews when it was first released. Sure the controls are a little clunky at times, and using anything similar to the turret or sniper rifle leaves you with a mouse sensitivity of around 100, but the gameplay is pretty fun. I enjoyed the stealth aspect of the game (made a spy type character) and the hacking/lockpicking/security "minigames"/puzzles were challenging at times, but not too difficult. If you have ~6-8 hours to waste, and can get this game for sale or in a Humble Bundle, I definitely recommend it.

Posted: December 16, 2015
Things that I liked:Dialouge options (more on this)Interesting Genre choice Perk systemStoryThings that I didn't like:Bugs (it's Obsidian)Stealth mechanicsGun playNote: I've generally liked every Obsidian game I've played despite problems with gameplay mechanics and general bugginess. After three playthrough and multiple different approaches to this game, I can say that I would recommend it to someone in the mood for something different. Espionage is commonly seen in the gameplay of Splinter Cell and other action shooters with a stealth component. This is an RPG centered around espionage where you basically play as Jason-Bourne, Jack Bauer, James Bond, or some combination of the three. Conversations are very well scripted and the characters are interesting, but the choice mechanic is nondescript (Aggressive, Suave, Professional). This is crucial because some conversations have a timed component. Based on the conversations and actions during the mission the storyline or flavor text will change slightly depending on which path you choose or who you befriend during the course of the game.  Final ending left a bit to be desired as it still had many loose ends to tie up and seemed to be setting up a franchise before Sega pulled the plug.Gameplay is very uninspired and based off the 3rd person cover shooter model. Feels like Splinter Cell or Hitman without the flexibility in combat and stealth that those games provide. There is also a problem with the stealth mechanic being buggy at some of the higher levels of difficulty. If you try to play without alerting anything, save early and often.This is not an open world RPG. It is a linear storyline driven RPG much in the same vein as KOTOR.Note: I have enjoyed every Obsidian game that I have played and I liked their predecessor, Black Isle Studios. Obsidian games absolutely set the tone of the world and the adventure.

												When this game was released, I paid way too much attention to the criticism. I passed it over.What a mistake!- for anyone who has played A LOT of video games and gets tired of the repetitive and derivative nature of most big releases (and even a lot of smaller titles), this game offers something pretty unique.If you like stealth games, if you like story-driven games, if you like the concept of branching paths that don't necessarily offer the usual dichotomy of simply good or evil, "winning" or "losing" a conversation, YOU NEED TO GIVE THIS A SHOT! Posted: March 3, 2014
												Alpha Protocol is a much maligned gem of a game. I'll not deny that it's rough around the edges; the controls are sub-par, and the level design is occasionally just bad.But the dialogue, the choices, and above all the consequences of those choices, these are all gold. The leveling system is comprehensive and covers a whole lot of options. The choices you make genuinely have repercussions; treat your handler well and they'll be good to you, but if they get too attached you might miss out on imprtant mission details. How you deal with enemies early on will impact what they do for (or to) you later. The story is extremely well put together and I think it makes up for the flaws.It's well worth a look.

Posted: May 11, 2015
												A new approach to the RPG genre.  Many good ideas, although some of them could have needed a bit more polish.  So sometimes the control could be a bit more smoothly and the sneaking parts can be frustrating, if not unfair.  The graphics is a little bit dated by now, but still looks like a good for DX9.  What I really like about the game is the fresh take with a new setting and a well made story.  Choices with consequences and good dialogues make the game quite replayable.  Be a secret agent, unravel secret conspiracies and get the bad guys, even though it's sometimes unclear who is on which side.  I really enjoy playing this game and I feel it really deserves a successor.

												When you go into the stupidly difficult boss battles, just tell yourself that its not unfair to you (the player), its proper punishment for Special A-Jerk Michael Thornton. And find your happy place until its over.In AP you get to dress up your MT doll to make him look like Michael Thornton is wearing a host of really bad disguises. You can choose from any three dialogue answers, which do sorta affect which perks you get throughout the game (no penalties, just bonuses or no bonuses).But mostly, its fun to see how far along the core team behind Deus EX:HR after creating this nonsense.You could try to plan your missions, if the game gave you any idea of the mission area layout ahead of time - you know, like a normal agent would?You could plan your weapon loadout if you had any idea what kinda opfor you were facing. Yup, none of that either.And despite allegedly belonging to a shadowy agency that is flush with safehouses and cash, you get stuck with whatever cash you pick up along the way, and a laughable black market economy that really only prevents you from getting any powerful weapons unless you scrimped all along until the final battle. Nothing handles character choice & consequence better and nothing comes close to handling stealth better.I include New Vegas, Deus Ex and V:TM - Bloodlines in that comparison, which amount for most of the competition. So if you're a fan of any of those games you might like Alpha Protocol. It definitely has "cult classic" written all over it and like Deus Ex it's way ahead of its time (or just too retro for its own good, depending on how you view the industry) with the way it integrates story with choice.The developers got slammed back when it released for their track record of buggy games, but there really isn't anything here worth complaining about if you're used to playing and appreciating western games that aren't published by Activision, EA and 2k games. A lot of the criticism was ignorant and misplaced blame on stealth and combat systems that reward investing skill points over raw player skill.

Posted: June 22, 2015
												Third-Person shooter/Stealth game with heavy RPG elements.The game has a strong narrative focus and enjoyable stealth and gunplay.The complex dialogue trees and smoothly integrated sidequests are the main replay value, as the rookie and veteran builds have their own dialogue options.Character advancement is fluid, and the high-level skills become overkill in many cases (eg: Chain Shot + Brilliance), while others become virtually essential (eg: Stealth and Infiltrator paths).Perks are interesting and well-implemented, and feel rewarding for trying different approaches to missions.The game is not without flaws, though.Movement and platforming feels restrictive, specially when compared to pure action 3d platformers.Cover also feels rigid, as some walls and objects don't allow you to hide behind or require you to approach at the right angle or distance to activate the option.Gunsights are not pinpoint acccurate, which leads to a certain frustration during fights, as bullets go stray all the time.Stealth is consistent enough, but tends to shift infrequently, making enemies spot you while on their blind sides some times and not reacting to you in front of them at others.The assault riffle only shoots 3-round bursts. It would've been awesome if you could use one-shot and auto-fire modes.But these flaws are not that significative, since the game is not meant to be an action shooter, full-on stealth or 3d platformer, but a narrative RPG where you can take multiple approaches to challenges.Gameworld design is more linear than comparable games like Deus Ex: Human Revolution, but is still open enough to allow multiple approaches to the same objectives most of the time.Dialogues are smooth and flow seamlessly, with nice voice acting. The in-mission chat with the controller adds to the experience, and the limited time to choose replies during conversation adds a degree of challenge to "cutscenes".Intrigue storyline is interesting and engaging, and changes according to what you did (or didn't) during previous missions, where you've been and who you've met before.Graphics feel a little dated for 2015, but that's a natural byproduct of technological advancement.

Posted: November 9, 2015
												It took me some time to like this game since the animation was so clunky and dialogue was ridged as a porn shoot.This game is clearly a console port, but since it was a RPG where choices matter I kept playing and I’ll say once you get a hang of it then it’s a cool game. The customization from character and loadout is nice so I was always eager to tinker with the weapon attachments making them specialized for a specific mission.The dialogue system was interesting and different from any RPG game I’ve played. In Alpha Protocol all your responses are done in “real-time”. This means when NPC’s are done talking you’re meant to spontaneously respond to their statement. It confused me in the beginning, but since it forces you to select a response within 10 seconds you’ll have to go with your gut reaction making the communication between NPC’s more realistic.When you need to hack a computer you’re meant use the mouse and keyboard to drag some numbers over each other, it’s difficult to explain – but my point is that in this case the developers couldn’t be bothered to port this properly for the PC. When you’re hacking with the mouse it’s the clumsiest user experience you’ve experienced. I was close to uninstall it at that point, but gave it a chance!I still recommend this game!Peace.

Posted: November 1, 2015
												The game has a ton of potential. It provides an interesting alternative to the stealth genre. That being said, it is a buggy mess. Grenades don't throw, the reticle ups and disappears, you glitch into walls and get stuck. It'd be one thing if this happened a few times throughout the single playthrough; this happens a few times in any given mission.I'm disappointed in the lack of polish more than anything. This game has a lot going for it, but then the bugs and wonky combat go and rear their ugly heads. I get that it's an "RPG" and not exactly an action game, but that doesn't forgive the lack of control customization. Anyone remember Secret of Mana? Great game, right? Remember how often you spent cycling through your rotary menu during a boss fight? Almost 90% of the fight was just rotary menus and spamming spells.Similar thing here, except unlike SoM, the bugs and lack of polish make the menu swapping far more annoying. It doesn't quite get the RPG playstyle aspect down - a tactical RPG would have been better for it. It tricks you into thinking it's Deus Ex or even a Splinter Cell stealth-action game, and then you remember the mechanics are blurry and it only emulates stealth action, it doesn't simulate it at all. Combat is just cover shooting, but it isn't smooth; sometimes I go to peak out and the camera swings every which way it feels like. Other times my reticle just disappears altogether.All that said, it still has its charms, and for the die-hard stealth addict who likes that element of Mass Effect of influencing people and their decisions affecting your game, this definitely has it. I have to give it a thumbs down, though; there are way better games to throw money at that will fulfill your stealth/cover shooter needs if you haven't exhausted those options yet. If you can get it for a $3 on a sale, go for it, you'll definitely get your money's worth; anything over $5 is pushing its value, though.

Posted: November 14, 2015
												While it doesnt live up to its potential, it is at the very least a decent game.  Character customization is very limited visually, but as far as playstyle goes it is pretty diverse. Players can customize their skill points and equipment to suit Full Stealth, Full frontal assault and everything inbetween.  AI is rather buggy but not in the way most stealth games are, they dont randomly see you through walls or across the map, they do however occasionally completely stop their assigned patrol route and just stand still until aggro'd or killed. Enemies will attempt to flank you if you stay in cover too long and throw grenades to force you out of cover.  Bosses for the most part are rather straightforward, but some are overpowered if you do not buy certain intel on them(a certain boss ignores knockback effects and brushes off punches while sprinting at you...)   Visually this game is not impressive, but it's not so out of date that it's glaring. Characters mouth movement feels natural enough that you dont feel the need to focus on it or attempt to ignore it *cough*life is strange*cough*   Combat is fairly balanced around range, headshots and time, though spread on guns is rather frustrating at times, it can be compensated for with various skill points/perks and upgraded weaponry. Melee is rather fun and reasonably strong, but often pointless vs bosses.If I were to rate this game out of 10?   Graphics 6/10Fun 7/10Story 4/10Gameplay 7/10   Overall: 6/10

Posted: September 16, 2015
												Do you like espionage RPGs that gives you choices, and makes impacts on the storyline and gameplay based on said choices? Then Alpha Protocol is for you!The GameIn the game, you follow the protagonist spy Mike Thorton, who's newly recruited into an agency program called Alpha Protocol. Thorton is sent on a mission in Saudi Arabia to kill Shaheed, the leader of a feared terrorist group Al Samad, as a retaliation response to them shooting down a commercial airlines plane.After having dealt with the insurgents however, things change for the worse and Mike Thorton is forced to become a rogue agent and uncover an evil plot from an american corporation, where he has to travel to Taipei, Rome and Moscow in order to gather intel and allies.The Ups+ Story   I found that the story was the most interesting part of Alpha Protocol, and was the biggest reason I kept playing through it. The game does an excellent job putting in twists to the story. The shady characters are often not as bad as you perceive, and the innocent characters are often more than they seem to be. + Stealth   Some reviewers had issues with the stealth in this game, though I experienced few problems with it. The game did feel a bit too linear at points, even though you had several points of entry to an objective, which made the stealth gameplay in those areas a bit less enjoyable, however overall I had great fun playing as a sneaky spy with maxed stealth abilities. *Hint: Shadow Operative is OP*+ Choices Matter   The choices you make in this game, and your decision on whether to go guns blazing into an objective, or take the non-lethal stealth approach without casualties has an impact on the storyline and gameplay. If you decided to take on an objective head on, Rambo-style, your next mission may have more security stationed around.+ Scenery   There's a nice change of scenery between Taipei, Rome, Moscow and Saudi Arabia, making each location feel refreshing enough and you get to go to a new area, before you start to get bored of the aesthetics in the old place.+ Email system   After every mission, you'll be checking your computer for emails containing story, dialogue, intel, etc. You get the option to reply to several characters, and some of the replies you can make are pretty fun and adds humor to the seriousness. You also get the chance to blackmail corporations, or choose to expose them in the media.+ Play as you like   With a diverse 'skilltree' you can choose whether you want to become an expert at stealth, sabotage, if you want to be a gunslinger with pistols, a close-up commando agent with shotguns, SMGs, and assault rifles, or be an expert martial arts fighter with nonlethal takedowns. The choice is yours!.. And The Downs - Minigames   When it comes to hacking, sabotaging or lockpicking, you will have to go through a minigame. These are annoying boring chores that you will encounter several times in each mission. Lockpicking is easy on PC, with sabotaging getting harder and especially hacking being a challenge. Thankfully if you don't enjoy these parts, you can stock up on EMPs and blaze through these sections, completely bypassing the minigames altogether. That's what I did when it came to hacking.  - Camera twitching   With this game being a console port, you will encounter camera twitching when you move your mouse around. After one hour gameplay, I had to search for a fix on this issue, as it was close to gamebreaking on my end. The good news; There's a fix for it! The bad news; I don't remember where I found it.- Combat   Combat in this game is mostly boring, and your guns are very (and I mean very) inaccurate unless you lock onto a target for an extended amount of time. The combat system takes some time to get used, but is less of a problem once you get accustomed to how it works, along with you putting more Ability Points into a weapon type. I went with Stealth and Pistol, being able to one hit K.O enemies from stealth, and using the ability Chain Shot on bosses for a fast and easy kill.- Dialogue options   I don't mind you only having a little time to reply during conversations, as that adds tension, but I dislike the system where you're only allowed to choose in what 'mood' you reply in. Do you wanna answer in a professional, aggressive or suave kind of way? I've chosen one 'mood' on several occasions and had my agent Thorton spit out some stupid crap I would never have picked in the first place. I prefer the Mass Effect style of dialogue instead of the way they're doing it in this game.The ResumeI wasn't expecting much from playing Alpha Protocol, but it actually surprised me. It has it's ups and down, especially with the combat. Having played through it now, I would most likely have bought it for the original price tag on Steam. If you're unsure whether or not this game might be fun for you, I can definitely recommend buying it through a sale, as it has several hours of gameplay and replayability to it, if you wish to see the story from different perspectives!

Combat is just cover shooting, but it isn't smooth; sometimes I go to peak out and the camera swings every which way it feels like. Other times my reticle just disappears altogether.All that said, it still has its charms, and for the die-hard stealth addict who likes that element of Mass Effect of influencing people and their decisions affecting your game, this definitely has it. I have to give it a thumbs down, though; there are way better games to throw money at that will fulfill your stealth/cover shooter needs if you haven't exhausted those options yet. If you can get it for a $3 on a sale, go for it, you'll definitely get your money's worth; anything over $5 is pushing its value, though.

												I think the game is great, but I went in with zero expectations. I also went into the game directly after finishing Mass Effect which added to my enjoyment. The game plays identically to ME1 but it made the mistake of being released after ME2 which convinced everyone the first game's controls were balls. Posted: May 24, 2015
												Alpha Protocol has player growth and skills similar to Deus Ex; missions, equipment, and stealth similar to Hitman; and far reaching dialogue choices similar to Mass Effect. So how does the amalgam work together? Not bad actually.Something novel to Alpha Protocol are the achievements, called perks. Where most games would give you a shiny meaningless badge saying "good work" after doing something interesting or noteworthy, Alpha Protocol's perks have mechanical effects. As an example, if you take enough beating without dying, you get a perk which talks about how tough you are and then gives you a bonus to your endurance (which lets you take still more of a beating).It's easier to talk about what went wrong than what went right. What's not so good about Alpha Protocol?The early and late story feels quite solid, but the story in some areas of the middle of the game has abrupt conclusions.Your dialog choices must be chosen before a timer expires. It isn't always obvious what some options refer to until the speaker finishes talking, but that's when the timer expires for picking your response!The mini-games are actually interesting, but the lock picking mini-game is highly dependent upon the sensitivity of your analog triggers and there are no settings to change the sensitivity; I have no idea how it works without a gamepad. There is one way around any mini-game which give all the same rewards, but it requires a consumable item.The game saves using checkpoints. You can copy a checkpoint save to be loaded later, but you can never save the game yourself. Many of these checkpoints are at extremely awkward or unpredictable occasions, like when you walk into a room with a bunch of baddies and turrets. Loading at those checkpoints can be unbearable. A good number of checkpoints cause events which prevent you from going backwards. As a person who likes to clean up all the baddies before exploring for hidden goodies, the checkpoint system bit me a number of times.For my own play through, I was accused of killing people that I had not killed. At the end of a particular mission, the statistics noted I killed nobody. However, the incident of me killing these people came up again and again. I'm not sure if it was because I destroyed some turrets or what, but that really broke immersion every time it came up.As with all games with a large selection of narrative and gameplay decisions, there are a lot of bugs. If you don't mind games with a lot of bugs and you are looking for an interesting blend of Deus Ex, Hitman, and Mass Effect, then this game is definitely worth picking up sometime.

												Alright, so this review will start out negative but there's a reason which I'll explain why you should give this game a go.So Alpha Protocol isn't great in many aspects: - The animations are jerky as the enemy's twitch when they turn and their walking isn't in sync to their steps, - Your aim is atrociously inaccurate that it would make a Xcom squaddie feel good about themselves.- The weapon selection is basically none, you have a choice of 1 weapon per-class as well as to identical tiers of the same gun.- Stealth is pretty basic, you're by no means Sam Fisher as you cart around enemies cone-of-vision, while trying to glue yourself to a wall.- Conversations....their ok but hardly Mass Effect in terms of depth or believability as your given a short time to choose a response and characters are oddly touchy or self-aware of exactly what kind of the 3 binary responses you made (like if you decide to be a bit playful and choose the "charm" option, they will tell you that you have a bit of a ego and will annoy your grumpy espionage course instructor)But...honestly, the reason why I...kind of been charmed and won over by it, is because the game concepts it takes on is compelling in it's own, sure it doesn't excelling in anything it attempts but it's a ambitious game and you get to do quite a lot in it, playing with many diffrent game mechanics in a short time, never feeling repetitive.Leveling your character up, sneaking, conversing, exploring and finding hidden objectives and loot in the levels, having consequenses for your actions, this game is something unique to be experienced but just don't go in to this with any high hopes and try to appreciate it for what it tried to do, that's all I can say.Besides, it's cheap as chips now-days anyway, so why not?

Posted: February 23, 2014
												The gameplay's pretty decent - in a lot of ways it feels like what Goldeneye and Perfect Dark should have been, if they hadn't been quite so limited by the technology of the day.  It bills itself as a spy RPG - this is only in as much as how Hollywood defines spies (or rather, how they did in classic movies).  There's a small information gathering feature that gives you some minor bonuses, but it's mostly just a stealthy shooter.  A good stealthy shooter that gets 2 of its 3 technical minigames very, very right.  Alarms rung by enemies can be canceled, but you have to finish a little minigame to do so (while being shot at unless you clear the area first), and lockpicking has its own minigame - both are actually very well done - you can figure out exactly what you need to do given a moment to think, but you're on a timer (every lock is connected to an alarm system, and alarms freeze you out so you have to start over) so you still feel pressured.  Hacking computers, the third technical minigame, is somewhat awkwardly controlled (move around 2 codes - mouse is hypersensitive and WSAD is super slow...and seems to not accept non-default Interact controls (anything but space...why space?) for finishing that side.  Much more challenging than the other two, but it's not game breaking since no matter how much you suck at it, you can level up your sabotage skill once and gain the ability for EMP grenades (wait, I thought this was the modern world) to selectively deactivate just the security systems of the device, allowing you to disarm alarms, kick through doors and hack computers without bothering with the minigame (yeah, definitely not using the standard version of an EMP).  All in all, what could be an excellent game.That is, until you hit the story.  There's a reason I said this would have been great for Goldeneye or Perfect Dark.  Those games had the sneaky, technical side of gameplay.  They had missions where you planted explosives, evaded detection of cameras, missions where using non-silenced weapons or allowing the enemy to fire their unsilenced weapons brought down what might be literally called an army of enemies down on you.  What they also had, however, and what Alpha Protocol lacks, is an interesting story.  Goldeneye's Dam-Facility-Runway introduction, and Perfect Dark's similarly tense infiltration mission were great hooks.  And while Goldeneye largely relied on you having seen the movie for the finer points, both games had interesting outside-the-box storylines when taken as a whole.  Alpha Protocol might venture outside the box eventually, but, to extend the metaphor of a story hook, you'd be better off using hook shaped pasta on the end of your fishing line than what Alpha Protocol provides.  After a short segment where you wake up confused in a hospital and beat down a number of guards while confusedly trying to escape this facility, you end up in a room talking to your boss as if nothing had happened (slightly jarring, but OK, whatever), you end up with your mission.  You are to kill the public face of an Islamist terrorist organization that used sophisticated ground-to-air missile technology to shoot down a civilian jet liner in the Middle East.  Did I just describe the basic story of about half the modern set shooters out there?  Yes.  Yes I did.  The antagonist is a transparent standin for Osama bin Laden and his organization is equally transparently standing in for Al Quaeda. Except that, since we're an intel organization so black ops that even black ops aren't allowed to know we exist...so black ops that we rely on weapons and information sales to fund our field operations.... we can't have anything big like 9/11 as a motivator, we need something more subtle.  So, instead of hooking you with its premise, the story stabs you with a piece of limp spaghetti.  Oh, and level design is pretty linear.  But then, I've just been playing Dishonored, where there's at least 3 ways to do anything, so perhaps I'm expecting too much.  (On the other hand, Obsidian's core team was Black Isle's core team - the guys who did the Infinity Engine DnD games, so expecting too much of them shouldn't be that easy.)It might get better with time.  It's a decent game, and, 2 missions in, has the potential to be something great.  It just needs a knife-in-the-back plot twist or two to get things going.  It's already provided me my money's worth of entertainment...but being on sale for $3.75 makes that a pretty easy threshold to cross.

Posted: March 23, 2014
												I've only played through two of the four operations so far in the game, but so far, I've enjoyed it immensely. Although the game totes itself as allowing the player to use different playstyles in order to progress, it is incredibly difficult to beat the game with a pure stealth build due to the boss fights that the player will inevitably come across. It took myself at least ten checkpoint loads in order to defeat the Russian mafia boss through the abuse of a low-leveled pistol skill that I had among the handful of higher leveled stealth skills that I had at my disposal (which were useless for anything other than for repositioning).Alpha Protocol is incredibly story driven where your conversations with the other characters in the game will affect future missions; if your handler doesn't like you, you get reduced mission bonuses and they will be less inclined to give you good information. Building and reading dossiers are also an important part for these conversations since it's possible to be intentionally mean to one character in order to boost your standing with another. You are warned in-game that a character that has too high of a good standing with you can potentially cause that person to act irrationally and cause problems for your missions, which is quite interesting.The combat is functional, but it doesn't really bring a ton of enjoyment. Stealthing the game is viable and you are rewarded if you sneak past enemies without taking them down (though you are also rewarded if you defeat/kill them). In fact, making it through missions undetected can affect future missions.It's something I'd recommend to those who enjoy espionage/thriller stories, though the game is not flawless.

Posted: April 2, 2014
												Alpha Protocol is a fairly decent game.  It has a lot of promise as an action-espionage game that combines stealth gameplay with social intrigue and roleplaying.  While it falls short, the target it was aiming for was a fairly high one, which puts the game at above average in my book.  It stumbled in its efforts, but it picked a rich, difficult goal, and it made a pretty good try.Positives:  Your decisions impact your gameplay and the story, the setting and factions are varied and interesting, and the interaction with the various characters is fairly well thought out.Negatives:  The game is pretty buggy, the save system is a course checkpoint system, and the action element is really lackluster.I would give this game a rough B grade.  It could definitely have been better, but I felt my time was well spent, and I will probably come back to this game in the future.  I spent roughly 25 hours on the game, and other than some frustrating mission conditionss and setup issues, I had a lot of fun.  I would recommend this game to people looking to invest their time in the setting and story, but not to those looking for to blow up some bad guys.BUG NOTE:  If you do try this game, make sure to keep action bound to spacebar for hacking in addition to your general preference.  You'll pretty much have to use the spacebar to lock in the keyboard side of a hack.

Posted: April 18, 2014
												This was a real buried gem of a game. I grabbed it during a sale for less than $5 on the thin promise of "Mass Effect with Super-Spies," and that turned out to be more or less exactly what was delivered. For all the negative press this game received, I found few flaws worth spiting the game for, and after two playthroughs I'm only disappointed I didn't find Alpha Protocol earlier.AP is a great find for people who enjoy RPGs with an emphasis on 3rd person action - not the other way around. The combat is fairly simple with a few nice twists, though certain combat styles are a touch overpowered while others feel heavily handicapped. If you're a gamer who looks for deep, challenging 3rd person combat, this isn't really what you're looking for. But it does offer rewards for people who are heavily into role-playing characters and only enjoy the action as a means to that end. Once I got a few of my combat skills ranked up enough, I started to feel like a serious Bond-level super-agent, which is exactly how I wanted to feel while playing.What Alpha Protocol brings to the table is a solid narrative with a few twists, a rich cast of interesting characters to inetract with, and a series of complicated moral quandries to navigate. The way you shape your character and his reactions makes a real difference in how the game feels - even if the levels you fight through are the same either way. Characters react to you differently depending on how you treat them (and others). I played through twice; once as a suave rookie agent in over his head, the next as a hard♥♥♥♥♥veteran willing to go to any lengths to get results. Each character felt unique, and my interactions with the NPCs felt different each time. My favorite parts of a great RPG are being able to shape a character, being surrounded by NPCs I care about or are interested in, and taking part in a story that grips me - or at least holds my interest while delivering enough surprises to keep me guessing. Alpha Protocol delivered that experience, along with a combat system that was fun and streamlined and made me feel like I was playing the kind of big screen super-spy I was hoping to create. So long as you go in without high expectations, but willing to overlook previous reviewers' complaints and have a fun time, I think you will. It was well worth it for me.
