												mmmmm.... so secret agents, 007 like moments, girls from around the world, and a corporation that is planning to control the world through fear of a cold war and now your agent is the only person who can stop them. Yeah Alpha Protocol has all these things, but jokes aside AP is actually a pretty fun game to play. AP's combat is not very unique but yet still satisfying to go through an area without anyone seeing you. But the combat is not what the heart of the game is; instead it's actually the choice's your character makes that defines the game. There is no good or bad choice only result's and it's these choices that defines who your character is by the end of the game. Every character you meet has a different personality and therefor reacts differently towards what you say, this in turn will affect how your 'handler' works with you on missions but the game can explain all of this better than me. If you haven't guessed this already Alpha Protocol is a must buy for anyone who's tired of these stupid Bond games and instead want to be an agent. While there are a few frustrating moments like the checkpoints or the wired loading thing how it affects the camera but these are a very small things that should not turn you off from buying this game. Overall Alpha Protocol is game that will make you enjoy your time while playing the game.

Posted: March 31, 2014
												Rough Around the Edges, but a Gem NonethelessObsidian's Alpha Protocol is like a cross between Deus Ex, Mass Effect, and Espionage. Deus Ex from its multi-method approach to your missions, Mass Effect for character choice and customizaion, and the three JBs (James Bond, Jack Bauer, and Jason Bourne) form your character Micheal Thorton's personality as the situation calls for it.The game is a first person RPG akin to Mass Effect, but with more emphasis on the RPG part. You need to invest skill points into your skills if you expect yourself to be compitent. Even after mastering some of those said skills you still will experience a bit of a challenge, at least on Hard. The game isn't molded around 1 play style, either. Wanna sneak in and sneak out on a mission? Do it. Do you want to leave the mission occasionally worrying about tripping on one of your victims? Do it!Also, unlike Mass Effect which has to factor the choices of a trilogy and trying to please everybody, Alpha Protocol didn't have such an expectation. Your choices will have an active impact on the missions. NPCs may have some kind of impression of you from actions and may or may not want to work for you because of it, or simply eliminating an arms dealer can jeopordize intelligence acquisition. And there's not always the "everybody lives" choice either, so you have to stick to the choices you make and how you influence NPCs.The presentation could have used some polish. The character animations  really show their seems sometimes, and Michael's dead ragdolling can cause him to rocket off somewhere. The inability to quick save really hampers some of the problem solving aspects, but somebody could argue that it's to prevent save-scumming. To me, it's a pain in the butt. Also, bodies just disappear. Having to hide them could have introduced another aspect to stealth, but alas the bodies just vanish like in Metal Gear Solid 1. Also, like most Obsidian games, expect a bug or two, but nothing gamebreaking.All and all, Alpha Protocol is a great game well worth it's price. The dialogue is sharp, snappy, and often times funny. The story has plenty of twists and curves to keep you interested, along with some well-designed characters that can keep you guessing. I'd recommend it regardless of the lack of needed polish. If you like your Action getting on your RPGs, this one is a winner.

Posted: April 5, 2014
												Honestly, I was ready to give up just a couple hours into this game: the camera was constantly zooming in and out when I walked by nearby objects (which is the entire time), the controls felt off no matter how I set the sensitivity, and the stealth mechanics seemed inconsistent.It's a shame that this game makes a terrible first impression, cause the first 2 problems can be fixed off the bat (look in community guides for the 'Camera Jerking Fix') with a little text file editing. The dev team should have done that for us PC users anyway. With those initial nags out of the way, I could focus on the gameplay better and got a grip on the stealth mechanics after a couple missions.Don't expect a really tight action game (this is an action RPG after all), but DO expect the action to be fun on its own terms. I beat the game twice; taking a stealth route the first time, then a guns-blazing route the second time. Both approaches worked well and were almost equally satisfying. Generally, the levels were easier playing as a stealthy character, but the boss fights were much easier as a walking tank character. I haven't even touched on the story which is the meat and potatoes of this game: it is AWESOME. You have a limited time to answer to other characters in a 'suave', 'aggressive', or 'professional' manner. As far as I know, this game originated the type of dialogue system also found in The Walking Dead. Your timed responses actively shape the story and you must deal with the (sometimes serious) consequences. Occasionally you don't get enough time to think things through but it's usually timed in such a way to make the conversations flow naturally. I won't ruin anything, but will mention that I immediately started a new game after the first go-around to try and uncover more of the story. Can't think of the last game I was that eager to play though again.Overall it has rough but enjoyable gameplay, and a great story with high replay value. 8/10

Posted: April 22, 2014
												I don’t get all the hatred that’s been directed at this game. I picked it up for $2 during a sale, and some professional game reviewers were warning to not even buy it at that price. Naturally, I had to see what all the fuss was about and…well…Alpha Protocol is really not a bad game.Not terribly original (a cross between Splinter Cell & Mass Effect in the CIA) and the story isn’t particularly memorable but the gameplay is solid & enjoyable. It’s not the best thing I’ve ever played but it is most certainly not the worst, either. That is, it’s strange to me when professional media praises total garbage like Dragon Age 2 yet trashes Alpha Protocol.I’ve seen other reviewers complain about the AI in Alpha Protocol and various other glitches. Never had any problem with either of those things. Graphics were nice, music and voice acting were both acceptable. The story is nothing groundbreaking and a bit predictable given the way espionage stories go these days (America is the REAL enemy! Dun dun dunnn!) but it’s still fun to engage in the different relationships and choices you can make which have a real impact on the plot. And the gameplay is the glue that holds everything together; not revolutionary but good enough. The only drawback to Alpha Protocol is that it’s rather forgettable and you won’t have any reason to replay it unless you want to witness some of the multiple story paths. You can expect to spend somewhere around 20 hours and will have a good time during that, though. It’s a shame that this first entry got savaged because it really could have turned into a good series. Instead we have Assassin’s Creed Part 8 and Final Fantasy 13 Part 3. Oh well.

Posted: April 18, 2014
												This was a real buried gem of a game. I grabbed it during a sale for less than $5 on the thin promise of "Mass Effect with Super-Spies," and that turned out to be more or less exactly what was delivered. For all the negative press this game received, I found few flaws worth spiting the game for, and after two playthroughs I'm only disappointed I didn't find Alpha Protocol earlier.AP is a great find for people who enjoy RPGs with an emphasis on 3rd person action - not the other way around. The combat is fairly simple with a few nice twists, though certain combat styles are a touch overpowered while others feel heavily handicapped. If you're a gamer who looks for deep, challenging 3rd person combat, this isn't really what you're looking for. But it does offer rewards for people who are heavily into role-playing characters and only enjoy the action as a means to that end. Once I got a few of my combat skills ranked up enough, I started to feel like a serious Bond-level super-agent, which is exactly how I wanted to feel while playing.What Alpha Protocol brings to the table is a solid narrative with a few twists, a rich cast of interesting characters to inetract with, and a series of complicated moral quandries to navigate. The way you shape your character and his reactions makes a real difference in how the game feels - even if the levels you fight through are the same either way. Characters react to you differently depending on how you treat them (and others). I played through twice; once as a suave rookie agent in over his head, the next as a hard♥♥♥♥♥veteran willing to go to any lengths to get results. Each character felt unique, and my interactions with the NPCs felt different each time. My favorite parts of a great RPG are being able to shape a character, being surrounded by NPCs I care about or are interested in, and taking part in a story that grips me - or at least holds my interest while delivering enough surprises to keep me guessing. Alpha Protocol delivered that experience, along with a combat system that was fun and streamlined and made me feel like I was playing the kind of big screen super-spy I was hoping to create. So long as you go in without high expectations, but willing to overlook previous reviewers' complaints and have a fun time, I think you will. It was well worth it for me.

												Alpha Protocol is a much maligned gem of a game. About two thirds of the (back)story takes place in non-voiced emails and other documents and the visual customization options for your character can be considered a joke at best.On a side note it's also really really good. Seriously.

												Fun RPG 3rd person shooter that has a good range of moral choices that lets you make your own operative. You could be a stealther sauve James Bond, or friggin wannabe Rambo. Posted: July 27, 2013
												I was really surprised at how good the game is. Don't believe the haters. Sure, combat and stealth don't match the AAA titles. Sure, there are some technical glitches (though I think most of them have been fixed by patches - I personally had just one little glitch throughout the entire game).But what makes it great is the story and a real sense that your choices affect what is happening later in the game. And not in small ways either - after finishing the game I've read how the last missions could look and it was quite different. Nice, Obsidian, nice.

Posted: November 22, 2014
												Pretty similar to a lot of Obsidians games, lots of choices and skill building, romances, factions and consequences during the game.Who you choose to side with, where you decide to go and what you choose to say all affect the game and the ending unlike mass effect where you have three colours, this game has many many endings which is pretty fun.On my first playthrough I chose stealth and pistols + martial arts, felt like I was playing mgs4 which was pretty cool there are lethal and non lethal takedowns which can also affect how much money you make and sometimes your standing with the factions.It also might have some bugs but I didn't encounter any gamebreaking ones search it up if need be I really enjoyed this game.Before I played the game I searched up the metascore and was turned off by the mixed reviews but I reccomend playing it anyway, Obsidian have made one bad game "Dungeon siege 3"

Posted: October 25, 2011
												This is one of the best bad games. Stealth mechanics, gunplay, meelee fighting, level design - it kinda goes "eh, good enough" with these a lot, and what's worse is that a lot of the time it bloody well isn't enough.But. Did you ever want to role-play as a spy? A real one that doesn't just sneak around, uses gadgets and shoots when it all goes♥♥♥♥♥♥up?THIS IS YOUR GAME.The good half of the game is basically a ridiculously elaborate and replayable Visual Novel. Every time you make a choice you only have a few moments to think and even a small joke to a co-worker can have consequences. Some of the conversations you have in this game really make you feel like you're on thin ice, close to ♥♥♥♥ing up. And when you do bluff someone, or get someone to slip by some crucial information, it feels all the better.And you can also play as an unkempt, irreverent jackass who's a veteran of combat and just shoots everything up - the game has got you well covered.

Posted: December 30, 2011
												Alpha Protocol got slammed pretty hard upon release, but I think that was mainly due to it failing (in certain people's minds) to live up to the hype brought about from its Game Informer feature. I bought the game for the PS3 after it dropped to ~$20, and it ranks as one of my favorite RPGs of the console. Skill tree customization, dialogue and action choices affect NPCs and the game at large, a fun spy thriller story--I didn't come here for elite gunplay mechanics; I just wanted an RPG, and that's what this is.

												This game had promise. But somewhere something failed. There is some roleplaying depth in the customization and the story. But it's all surrounded with ugliness. Posted: July 1, 2012
												The game is not perfect: the graphics could be better, the choice of controls is not very nice for PC gamers and, of course there are some bugs. But I think this game is totally worthy a try. The plot is not easily predictable and the gameplay is largely dictated by our own actions - be it our choices in dialogues or the way we complete missions. Here, we can control what will happen later in the game. That means that we can actually replay the whole game more than just once - with different choices of friends and foes and, of course, different styles: from stealth or melee to "Rambo-like".Some more cons:Minigames - only 3 are available and it is not easy to solve them with keyboard and mouse.Saving system: we cannot save whenever we want but we can only "copy" the last checkpoint.Some more pros:Dialogue options and other choices must be made quickly, which is different from many games, making it more realistic and challenging.Weapons, armour and appearance can be customised.

Posted: December 27, 2011
												This game received a really terrible reputation as buggy, with a weak, story and stiff characters.  Yes, it has bugs, and the character animations aren't always the best, but the story is good, the game is still a ton of fun, and it feels a great deal like Mass Effect.  Your decisions do affect the story, who you ally with and the overall game.  I see this game coming up on Steam for $2-$5 duirng their specials, and anyone who doesn't grab this game for that amazing price will be missing a great experience (at an amazing price!)

												This game is an unsung gem that has slipped through the perverbial cracks.  This title skilfully combines stealth gameplay with rpg elements and an effective story. Posted: January 28, 2015
												This game is very enjoyable and engaging. At least 8.5/10. I did an an entire playthrough and did not encounter a single glitch, let alone a game-breaking one. I'm not sure why everyone seems to have a problem with that aspect.That being said, the game has some problems. The skills available on the skilltree( (and there are many) are not always balanced with one another, making it more crucial that you get the right skills early. That in conjunction with the horribly disproportionaltly difficult bosses, can mean that you could spend an extra 4-5 hours on top of the 15 it takes to complete the game just trying to beat the F****** bosses. (I'm talking about you, Brayko, Darcy, and most of all you, helicopter. F*** you...) Anyways, loved the game. Thinking about a second playthrough.
